DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND OTHER SERVICES (COMPENSATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill seeks to amend the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Act 1995. The Health and Other Services (Compensation) Act 1995 was put in place to ensure that the Commonwealth was repaid when people who have used Medicare or nursing homes receive a compensation payout to cover these costs. In practice the act forced insurers to withhold payouts to people injured at work or in motor vehicle accidents until any debt owing to the Commonwealth was paid.

SPEECH.PARA: The act was passed with bipartisan support during the life of the last parliament. The act took effect on 1 February this year but it has become quite obvious that there have been significant delays in the early operation of the act. This has meant that many people have been forced to wait several months to receive their payouts. In many cases the sums which are owed to the people concerned are considerable and interest only accrues up until the date of the court judgment or the date of settlement. No interest is earned during the period of the delay by the person who has been injured.

Several of my own constituents have suffered as a result of these delays. One in particular had a payment of $75,000 frozen for several months while he and the Health Insurance Commission exchanged letters to seek to determine how much was specifically owed to the Commonwealth. This case has now been resolved, but I have been contacted by a very large number of other Labor members and senators who have raised further cases of individual hardship. This is the issue that the bill will address, how to speed up the release of compensation payments while protecting the Commonwealth's right to be repaid.

The aim of the bill is to change the withholding requirements. Rather than withholding the entire compensation amount, this bill will only withhold the total amount of Medicare benefits paid since the injury occurred. In the majority of cases this will mean that claimants will receive over 90 per cent of their payout within 14 days of the settlement of their claim.

The key amendment requires that, once a case has been settled, the Health Insurance Commission at the claimant's request must provide within 14 days a notice giving the total amount of Medicare benefits paid on the claimant's behalf since the injury occurred. Only this total of the Medicare benefits payments will be deducted from the compensation sum and the balance will be released to the person who has been injured. Having subsequently negotiated about which of the withheld benefits are to be repaid, the claimant will then receive the balance of any other amount withheld within three months.

These are well balanced amendments which will enable people to get earlier access to the majority of their compensation payouts while ensuring that the Commonwealth does not lose out. I was pleased to note recently that the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) also expressed concern in the House about this problem. I have to say I am a little disappointed that in answer to a dorothy dixer in question time he scored a few political points but did not indicate whether he would be supporting a legislative change to address the problem. I therefore hope that the minister will support my private member's bill to address this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got our support.

—I appreciate the support of the member for Chifley on every occasion. No doubt the minister and his department, like the opposition, have received many calls and letters from people who have been affected by these delays. The minister has certainly been aware since 22 May when he scored those cheap political points here in question time. The minister should also be aware of the diff iculties that have been caused by the legislation which both parties supported during the life of the last parliament. In fact he quoted cases of people who have had lump sums of up to $1 million being delayed by very small amounts owing to Medicare.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of deep regret that to date the minister has not announced any action or intention to legislate to address these problems. It is my hope that this private member's bill will not only get speedy consideration, but at the very least this private member's bill will increase the pressure on the minister to come up with a proposal which ensures that people are not unfairly treated by unreasonable delays in releasing compensation payments. I commend the bill to the House and I seek leave to present an explanatory memorandum on the operation of the bill.
Leave granted.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Not every Australian has had recourse to use the Office of the Ombudsman and, in terms of Commonwealth agencies, it is a very modest office costing a little over $8 million a year. I should say to the House that, in 1994‐95, 4,565 written complaints and 12,444 oral complaints were received, making a total of 17,019 of our fellow Australians seeking to use the Ombudsman.

SPEECH.PARA: The office of Ombudsman is one of the important cornerstones of our human rights infrastructure in Australia. It is fair to say, and I will quote from a parliamentary report:
Most honourable members on either side, and senators for that matter, support human rights in this place.

A lot of members were particularly concerned about newspaper reports that the budget of the Office of the Ombudsman was going to be cut quite severely in this budget round. It caused me some concern. In the child support inquiry, I got to know the Ombudsman, Philippa Smith, very well. It became a real puzzle to me why her consistent criticism of the Child Support Agency had been neglected by the parliament and the government.

This bill seeks to redress a situation about which I have some concern—that is, the Ombudsman tables her report as a statutory office holder in the parliament each year and, regrettably, no committee of this House actually looks at that report. This parliament could set up a joint committee—and it is not proposed that it would have a permanent secretariat—which would meet on a needs basis, receive her report and make sure that appropriate action was taken. Over 40,000 of our fellow Australians sought recourse to the Ombudsman in 1994-95. She has brought down a very useful report, and I will quote a few lines:

As an externally independent review agency, the Ombudsman can and does, to use the words of Justice Lee, bring the lamp of scrutiny to otherwise dark places, even over the resistance to those who would draw the blinds.

Here we are talking about public service departments, Commonwealth agencies, ordinary citizens and, I might say, small businessmen, if you read this report, who have been forced as a matter of last resort to contact the Ombudsman to secure their rights under the law because the Ombudsman insists that public administration must be consistent with the law. More than that, she highlights shortcomings either in her powers or in trends of the law. For example, she notes in her latest report that `there is much contracting out within the Commonwealth public sector'. She does not object to it but she highlights the fact that these are creating new complaints and new areas of concern and that legislation is deficient. Something needs to be done.

I cannot report to the House that anything is being done about her report. My bill will redress that situation. She points out where people have exceeded their powers, for example, in relation to a customs search. When ordinary citizens or small business approach the Ombudsman, they do not go to the chamber magistrate and they do not engage a solicitor or a barrister because the service is free of charge.

The guts of the private member's bill is this: it is not the Ombudsman who has failed the parliament; it is the parliament who has failed the Ombudsman and the 40,000 of our fellow Australians who have contacted the Ombudsman. We are declining to listen to the needs of the people who have contacted the Ombudsman. I seek leave to present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.
Leave granted.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House:
(1) condemns the racist comments made during the last federal election campaign and deplores the use of racism as a tool from which to gain political mileage;
(2) recognises that Australians, whatever their race, creed or political beliefs, should never become victims of racial vilification or denigration;
(3) recognises the achievements of Australia's indigenous population and endorses the continuing process of reconciliation between non‐indigenous and indigenous Australians; and
(4) recognises the achievements of Australia's immigration policy since 1945.

Calling someone a racist is quite rightly an accusation not to be made lightly. However, it is a word that is used carelessly at times. In the past, we have all seen it aimed unfairly at people who had a genuine interest in discussing our country's immigration policy. It is a charge that has been unjustly thrown at people concerned that the government's policies on indigenous Australians were not working as effectively as they could have been.

There is often a fine line that divides sensible commentary on these issues and racial vilification. We should be able to accept that people can walk that fine line without necessarily tipping over into racism. We should defend their right to speak about these issues at all times.

The word `racism' to me carries with it strong connotations and evokes pictures in my mind which I take no great pleasure in revisiting. I am reminded of sitting on a train in tears as a young person while the passengers behind me were insulted and abused in front of the entire carriage by a respectably dressed gentleman simply because they were speaking in their own language. I am reminded of my husband's stories about his experiences of racism as a result of his Italian heritage—never mind the fact that he was born in Broken Hill. I am reminded of the personal testimonies concerning racism, often involving verbal and sometimes even physical abuse, made to me by my constituents during my 25 years in public life.

Yet, while racism is a charge not to be made flippantly, we should never shrink from its use when appropriate. Each of us has a duty—and I say `us' meaning all Australians, not just members of parliament—to stand up and expose racism wherever it exists. Racism is insidious. It can spread like a cancer through our society. For it to run unchecked is to ask for it to consume us from within until we can no longer stand out against it.

Racism is nothing new. Australia has had its own experiences with racism just as every other nation on earth has been touched by it. In the past, through our ignorance and naivete, racism was officially sanctioned in legislation and the constitution—I am referring, of course, to the White Australia policy and our past treatment of Australia's indigenous people, only granting them the status of Australian citizenship via referendum in 1967. Yet, like many, I thought those days were far behind us. My seat of Prospect is one of the most ethnically diverse in the country and yet the level of racial disharmony remains, thankfully, incredibly small—a testament to the success of Australian immigration policy since 1945.

I thought the Australia portrayed in John O'Grady's They're a Weird Mob—a nation comically uncertain and suspicious of outsiders—had long since vanished. It was during the last election campaign that I realised how wrong I had been. Rather than simply existing among a small lunatic fringe, it seems that racism is still alive and well in mainstream Australian society—a fact evidenced by the comments made by certain candidates during the campaign, and from the massive support some of these people received on election day.

The election had not even been called when on Australia Day, of all days, we heard the first of what would be many racist remarks by pre-selected candidates across the country. That first racist remark came from northern Queensland and was echoed, via our nation's media, to all corners of the country. What sickened me was that this particular person, after making this and other comments, rather than recognising their tastelessness or their capacity to offend most Australians, went on to say:

Judging by the response in the local media . . . and slaps on the back we've had as we've been going around the shopping centres and doing our normal doorstops on the hustings and knocking on doors, I would say the kerfuffle that happened would be worth about 90 per cent positive for us in this seat.

For this man, racism had seemingly brought instant reward—and in the end it did prove to be a winner of sorts. This particular candidate on election day, whilst not gaining a seat in this parliament, managed to elicit close to a seven per cent swing in his vote.

With no small thanks to a campaign based on racial vilification and denigration, other candidates managed to go that one step further and take their seats in this place. One victorious candidate said that her win was for the `white community' and that now in Canberra she would fight for `anyone apart from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders'—a comment which I take as a slur upon our country's democratic traditions and our role as representatives of the people.

In my own election battle in the seat of Prospect, one candidate, encouraged by the idea of receiving electoral reward for his racism, suggested that Australia's immigration policy was `skewed' in favour of particular races and that he would like to see more `northern Europeans'. I could go on and on, but that would be unnecessary. I am sure all honourable members are familiar with what comments were made and by whom.

These people made their insidious comments cloaked by the argument that they were bucking against `political correctness'. Their twisted logic figured that racial vilification was okay because for far too long Australians had been told what to think by the `thought police' in Canberra and that now they were fighting back. The great smokescreen of `anti-political correctness' was being used by these candidates to justify racism, pure and simple.

We did not hear a sensible and judicious questioning by these candidates of the government's immigration policy, as is every Australian's right; we heard gutter talk about `slanty-eyed ideologues'. We did not hear these candidates raise discussions on the merits of citizenship; we heard base references to `dewogging ceremonies'. We did not hear from these candidates constructive criticism on ways in which the government could better structure or focus its policies on Aboriginal Australians; we heard hate-mongering and contemptible sneers about `how the blacks have never had it so good'.

I do not think it is an exaggeration for me to say that these candidates searched voters for feelings of economic uncertainty and concern for the future—those same feelings which were tapped by the Nazis prior to 1933. They sought out this uncertainty, and they gave it a focus. They found a target against which these feelings could be expressed. They gave their supporters a scapegoat.

It has been suggested by some that these candidates deserve nothing but our ridicule and that we should marginalise them. I reject this argument. These people stopped existing on our periphery when they achieved national exposure for their comments and vaulted their way into federal parliament. We need to condemn them—publicly and persistently.
I am reminded of a quote from Martin Niemoller:

When Hitler attacked the Jews I was not a Jew, therefore, I was not concerned. And when Hitler attacked the Catholics, I was not a Catholic, and therefore, I was not concerned. And when Hitler attacked the unions and the industrialists, I was not a member of the unions and I was not concerned. Then, Hitler attacked me and the Protestant church—and there was nobody left to be concerned.

The lesson is there: we cannot afford not to be concerned about this racism in our midst. It reflects upon us all. It threatens us all. Australia has a rich history of bipartisan support on matters concerning race and ethnicity. Let us join together once more in this spirit and again condemn racism of all kinds—and in particular those who seek to profit from its use.

We have much to be proud of in our past immigration policies and our present determination to bring about Aboriginal reconciliation. Let us not allow the racists in our ranks to hold us back or sap our strength on these issues. Let us treat them with the contempt and scorn they so richly deserve. That is why I commend the motion appearing in my name on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: — Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak to this motion today. I congratulate the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) on putting it forward and I must say that I agree with her comments made here today.

SPEECH.PARA: Most people in this House are here to do some good for Australia and are motivated by a strong sense of duty to the Australian people. This has been reflected in many of the maiden speeches that have been made since the new government was elected, and I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate people who have made their maiden speeches and who have referred to their personal hope and idealism for a better Australia.
It is also a great pleasure to sit in this House with, for example, the member for Petrie (Ms Gambaro). She is the first female of Australian‐Italian origin to take a seat in this place.

I have already said in this House that, `regardless of which side of the chamber we sit on, we represent one nation'. It is a pity that only a handful of individuals in this place, none of whom can be described as being major players in Australian politics, have made unfortunate remarks in the lead-up to the recent election. It has guaranteed them a level of publicity they would otherwise not have attracted. Their agendas are not in the best interests of Australia, nor are they supported by the major political parties represented in parliament.

Often their defence has been the comment that, as a democratic body, the parliament is here to represent all opinions in the Australian community. That may well be true, but elected members also have an obligation to show leadership in the area of social consciousness and enlightenment. This is how the Westminster form of government has evolved into the most effective way to guarantee rights and liberties to all individuals and why it has been imitated throughout the world as a model to ensure progressive social policy. I am sure that these sentiments are shared by the vast majority of members in this House—they are typically broad‐minded and inclusive and would not wish to linger on divisiveness and the tired debates which have racist overtones.

The member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), who is a former member of the Labor Party, made the comment in 1991 as an ALP member that reform such as the New South Wales racial vilification law is `not the proper vehicle to teach such morality. In a democracy the truth should never be proclaimed by the state'. I disagree. Morality is generated by families and by tradition and enlightenment within the larger community and by the fears and the needs of that community. If it is not proclaimed and enshrined in the state then where else?

When the now Independent member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) made inappropriate comments during the campaign the Liberal Party acted quickly and decisively and her endorsement was removed. The member for Kalgoorlie for years had been making inappropriate comments in addressing right wing fringe groups and it took Labor years to expel him. The Liberal Party condemns, and in the words of the motion of this House, `the use of racism as a tool from which to gain political mileage'.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the truth's coming out now.

—For her own benefit, I remind the member that she has not made her maiden speech and it might be in her best interests to listen. The Liberal Party believes in individuals. It is therefore naturally suspicious of generalisations and assumptions about groups or communities of various peoples. The Liberal Party—I am happy to say—has and will continue to embrace multiculturalism and real reconciliation with our indigenous communities.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate surrounding these issues has often been vigorous, but the intention and motivation has always been to deliver the best possible assistance to new Australians and to indigenous Australians. The Liberal Party also believes that, again in the words of the motion before us, `Australians, whatever their race, creed or political beliefs, should never become victims of racial vilification or denigration'.

In my own electorate of Adelaide it has been a longstanding privilege for me to work with the various communities and to attend the many social functions hosted by the immigrant and ethnic communities. It reminds me of Australia's outstanding history of immigration which I will go on to discuss. In the last few months I have attended St Patrick's Day festivities, the celebration of the Vietnamese, Chinese and Cambodian new years and Greek and Italian festivals. I have also been involved in organising the most successful meeting between John Howard and leaders of the Greek community in mid‐1995.

Twenty‐five per cent of all my constituents in Adelaide were born overseas and we live harmoniously together. During the recent campaign, I am proud of the fact that members of the Italian, Greek and Vietnamese communities all were associated with my campaign and helped me. I am most happy to have been associated with them.

In the wake of the vast exodus from Europe after World War II, Australia agreed to participate in an international scheme to resettle many of the world's displaced persons. Although the White Australia policy was officially removed from the ALP platform in 1965, it received widespread support from some individual members within that party for many years after. In the late 1940s, the ALP refused the Japanese wives of ex‐servicemen entry into Australia. In 1949 Labor's War‐time Refugee Removal Act was intended to expel some 9,000 Asian refugees who had decided to stay in Australia after the war. One of the first acts of the Menzies government was to allow these people to stay.

In 1966 the Liberal government abolished the White Australia policy which had been in place since Federation. During the 1960s the Liberals also abolished the discrimination against non‐Europeans with respect to various pensions and social services. In 1977 the Fraser government accepted Vietnamese boat people. The decision was vehemently opposed by the ACTU and its then president, former Prime Minister Bob Hawke. A bipartisan approach to this issue was not possible given Labor's concern about the possible anti-communist background of these people.

In 1978 the Fraser government expanded the terms of the family reunion scheme and the nine principles adopted to guide immigration policy at that time remain essentially unchanged to this day. In the late 1970s the Department of Immigration was renamed the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and the Ethnic Affairs Council and the Federation of Ethnic Community Councils of Australia were established.

Australia's immigration policy since 1945 has indeed been impressive, not only because of the numbers that have come to this country but also because of the cultural changes that we have seen. People tell me all the time in the electorate that we no longer just have fish and chip shops; we now have different restaurants and cafes on the footpaths. The different accents that one hears blend in and I am sure that has made us a much better country. We are also a very much more tolerant society than we were and the envy of other parts of the world for the way that we have managed to live with tolerance and harmony. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has recently stated that the coalition:

. . . remains committed to reconciliation. That commitment can't stop us from ensuring the full accountability of all those who have the taxpayers' money for the expenditure of that money, and ATSIC is no different and the Aboriginal Legal Service is no different from any other agency of Government . . . which is funded by the Australian taxpayer.

There is no legitimate ground for the leaders of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community in Australia to believe that the new Government . . . is going to stop the process of genuine reconciliation.

As set out in the coalition's election commitments, reconciliation cannot proceed `until disadvantages in health, housing, education and unemployment and the high incarceration rates are overcome'. These are big challenges but they must be met.

Despite over $1 billion in funding per year, the Aboriginal health, housing, education and employment prospects remain miserable. All Australians are exasperated by the lack of progress and the failure of this high level of funding to make inroads into the high level of disadvantaged people witnessed in our Aboriginal communities.

As stated in the coalition's pre-election statement on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, indigenous health is the worst of any indigenous group in the developed world. Indigenous unemployment is four times that of other Australians and is rising despite increases in community development employment program funding. Less than a third of Aboriginal children complete secondary school. My own studies of Aboriginal health in places like Burke, Wilcannia and Walgett reveal wide‐ranging criticism of ATSIC and a desire, particularly from Aboriginal women in those communities, for a real change in the way it is administered.

Direct Commonwealth assistance to indigenous Australians commenced under Prime Minister Gorton, while the McMahon government introduced funding for land purchases and commercial development in 1976. The Fraser government passed the Aboriginal Land Rights Act, which remains the most far-reaching land rights legislation in Australia.

The coalition, while proud of its record, recognises that there can be no complacency and there is still much more to be done. No political party represented in this House has a monopoly on the high moral ground when discussing immigration, racism and reconciliation. There is within the Australian population a small number of people with residual but receding strains of racism, but the vast majority of Australians are generous, broad‐minded and inclusive. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that on this occasion we again have an example of the way in which both sides of this House can find common ground. The member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) has been followed by the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), and both have made I think very substantial contributions which do honour to this House.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there is a temptation amongst some of the critics of positions that are taken by the government and by the opposition to say that there is some lack of capacity for debate when mainstream parties find common ground, that they are squeezed out. They sometimes call this political correctness. The truth is we should not underestimate the value to the Australian community that comes from the great political parties of this country finding common ground on some issues.

I have been critical of some fraying at the edge of that bipartisanship in the area of immigration and ethnic affairs, for which I have responsibility as a shadow minister. I have been critical of the two-year waiting period decision of the coalition. I think, ironically, it will have an effect quite contrary to that which has been perhaps at the back of the minds of some who have supported that. It seems highly likely that if people are forced into situations where they are compelled to wait two years without benefits, were that to occur, and without a proper safety net then only the very wealthy or the desperate would come.

When that situation is coupled with an emphasis on English language skills, then, paradoxically, it is highly likely that our immigration intake would be skewed further towards those from the Asian region rather than towards what used to be traditional source countries. These are the ironies and paradoxes that emerge when one, in a sense, seeks to indirectly achieve that which is indefensible directly.

BREAK.PARA: It is true to say that since the days of Malcolm Fraser we generally have found ourselves in broad agreement, and that has been very important for us as a community, as a nation. It is not surprising that there are still some within the Australian community who do not agree with the positions that are taken by both major parties, the National Party and the Democrats on this area of policy. Why is that? Because for a very long period of time we did have, supported by both sides of the Australian political system, a White Australia policy. It is within my lifetime that that policy existed and was maintained and defended.

It is hardly surprising that there are some within our Australian community who still feel troubled by that change. It will be fertile ground for demagogues and those who wish to play the racist card in public life in any society. Le Pen in France is a good example of that, as are some of the more recent phenomena that we have seen in Australia. I simply hope that the good sense and the tolerance of the Australian community are able to reject those appeals to intolerance that may have been exampled in some other societies.

A report in the Sydney Morning Herald gives some reason for confidence in that. Whilst there is concern about the level of migration intake into Australia, the huge preponderance of people who expressed that concern sheeted it home to concern about unemployment. I say straightforwardly that there are many academics of good standing who would say that that concern is unplaced, not justified, and that in fact bringing people in from overseas is actually an employment stimulator. But, of course, that runs counter‐intuitively; it runs against people's own gut instincts.

The concern expressed about immigration was not based on racial grounds. Indeed, there was overwhelmingly strong support by much more than a simple majority for our programs of multiculturalism, programs which were endorsed by both sides. I think it is very important in this debate for us to stand up strongly and endorse the principles of the member for Prospect.

Finally, I turn to some of the documents that have been circulated more recently by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). She has produced a fairly misleading set of documents that suggest that Aboriginal people in Australia are treated in a way which is prejudicially to their benefit, to a degree which is unjustifiable. Let us be blunt: firstly, if you look at indices of disadvantage in Australia, Aboriginal Australians are up there right at the top. Secondly, her data was wrong. For example, she claimed there was no program for children in rural Australia. There is, and it is the assistance for isolated children scheme. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I broadly agree with the sentiments expressed in this debate, but I am not quite sure why the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) has raised these matters in this House in the form that she has. I am looking at the four points that she has raised and I find some of them objectionable—in particular, that after 50 years of postwar migration we are still talking about the achievements of Australia's immigration program. I am part of that immigration program, and I find it offensive that we are still saying around Australia or in this parliament, `Isn't it great that we have a migration program that is working well.' Surely it is a fact of life, and we should not be using this parliament—
—That's why I said in my speech—if you had been in here to listen—that we've got to keep on saying it because people are making a lot of comments.

—The point made is that we should not keep on saying it. I do not think that is right. I do not think we should keep speaking about multiculturalism, for instance, in the form that the honourable member for Prospect has raised it. The debate should not be about multiculturalism itself but about how to make it work even better than it has been working in the past. We have one of the great migration programs in the world—we are one of the great multicultural nations of the world—and I do not think we should be talking about that in any form other than how we should be making it even better. Different to what has been said today, we should keep saying that it is great to have a migration program.

SPEECH.PARA: The third paragraph of the honourable member's motion states that the House `recognises the achievements of Australia's indigenous population'. I feel very strongly about that. Whilst, without doubt, there have been some advances made in Aboriginal affairs, the fact is that when you look at the socioeconomic standing of the Aboriginal community vis-a-vis the white community, you see that they have gone backwards.

I do not think it is right for us to talk about the achievements of the indigenous people when they continue to have the worst socioeconomic standing of anyone in Australia, the most disadvantaged in Australia. Whilst we are talking about indigenous people having made advances, all I am saying is that the advances have been mediocre compared with what white Australians have achieved.

I have spent a lot of time on Aboriginal affairs. I have spent three years travelling all around New South Wales. I have been from the north to the south and the east to the west. I have seen the struggle of the Aboriginal community—in many instances not their fault but the fault of the white administration that has been put in to oversee their progress.

The second paragraph of the honourable member's motion states that the House `recognises that Australians, whatever their race, creed or political beliefs, should never become victims of racial vilification or denigration'. The fact is that all parliaments in all states have sufficient legislation to deal with racist comments or racial vilification. If the honourable member had specific matters that she wanted to raise in this parliament, then let us talk in specifics rather than in generalities. It does upset people to say that racial vilification or denigration goes on without there being any grounds for action being taken to stop it. In fact, I think there are sufficient measures in place in a free society to deal with this matter.

The first paragraph of the honourable member's motion states that the House `condemns the racist comments made during the last federal election campaign and deplores the use of racism'. There is no question that I agree with her in regard to that first part of her motion. There is absolutely no reason for people to use racist comments to try and improve their standing in the electorate. I agree with the honourable member and I find deplorable some statements made by some people who have been elected to this parliament, using racist terminology to get themselves elected. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In a recent Sydney Town Hall Liberal Party bunfest, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . importantly, one of the other goals I set myself, was quite simply to bring about a restoration where people felt a little more freely, if the mood struck them, to talk about controversial issues without fear of being branded as a racist or some kind of other bigot for daring to raise those subjects.

Unfortunately, that comment was eerily reminiscent of the response of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) on 22 February to comments by a number of his candidates. He said in the Australian that he deplored `politically correct agenda setters' and that he was concerned that his own comments would be overmagnified and that the media would `ratchet up a few more notches in magnification of every utterance deemed to be either incorrect or unusual or whatever'. He went on to say that he felt people were stopping debate on migration by these kinds of allegations.

That led to my documentary history, Aborigines in white Australia: a documentary history of the attitudes affecting official policy and the Australian Aborigine, which was one of the first Australian reference books to document the evolution of relationships and our transition from intolerance to a recognition of the need to do much better to ensure equality of life experience and respect for all in our society.

The classic American sociologist, Gordon Allport, wrote many years ago that, `Racial prejudice is uneconomic, it is fertile ground for violence and war, it is trivialising to human reason, and is not, never has been and never will be a good thing in human society.' Throughout history, societies have made sharp distinctions between `them' and `us'—in other words, the home community and outsiders. The step from differentiating one group from another to attributing inferior qualities to the other is very small but is not inevitable or immutable. We have to learn from a very early age that to be different is not to be inferior.

Until 1965 Aboriginal men and women working in the northern Australian pastoral industry, for example, were not paid wages but, instead, received rations. These rations were often of the poorest quality. In granting equal pay, however, the tribunal excluded women workers and inserted a slow worker clause, giving an out to the employer who could then pay a minimum rate in protecting the European worker. How did we justify that? We referred to racial differences. We referred to the fact that the Aboriginal worker was somehow innately less able to put in a hard day's work and was somehow less physically able to sustain long, hard work.

There is a great deal of evidence to suggest that racism, ethnic prejudice and its consequences are very often the unconscious rationalisation of economic exploitation, particularly in our country. When resources become scarce, one group will often justify their greater access or winning of what is to be had by some reference to the other's racial or ethnic inferiority. For example, when the gold started to run out last century, the Chinese, who were numerous and diligent on the gold fields and did a lot better than some of our European ancestors, became the focus of Australian racial hatred, vilification and eventually violence. This hatred became institutionalised in the poll taxes levied on Chinese arriving and in attempts to exclude them altogether from mining in the territories where gold was found later in the century. It eventually fed into the White Australia policy.

As the struggle for work among the less skilled and tradesmen intensified at the turn of the century, the white workers in the fledgling trade union movements banded together for white labour only policies. Much of the furniture produced at the turn of the century was stamped very neatly on the back `European labour only'.

BREAK.PARA: But we have come a very long way from all of that. Our language and our literature and, more importantly, our laws reflect that long, hard path that we have travelled. Today most of us stand proud to list the differences among the cultural groups which make up our pluralist society. At the same time, however, we must ensure that, wherever there is pressure in some part of our society, whenever the poorest of one group find themselves competing with the poorest of another, we do not allow those differences to be exploited by reference to racial inferiority or ethnic difference as some sort of rationalisation for one group getting more.

We have come a long way since we applauded Sir Paul Hasluck in 1951 for announcing the assimilation policy. We moved on from assimilation to integration. Now we have to be vigilant that we glorify the differences in our community and never again make reference to the fact that to be different is to be unequal.
I therefore support the member for Prospect and the other speakers who spoke in a similar vein most strongly. I hope that this record of our concerns will be used and reflected upon in years to come.

I hope that, in starting this process tomorrow, it will result in a very good conclusion for our city and our nation. The potential of the north-west minerals province is probably the most exciting potential in the whole of the world. I look forward to being a part of that. I ask the parliament and the government to look to that long-term vision for our country, to bring the prosperity that is so sorely needed back to the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to condemn the government's slow torturing of those involved in the skillshare program. Initially, the government indicated that they would cut a third of the skillshare budget, with no guarantees whatsoever beyond 30 September. But, upon public pressure, the government last week indicated that that funding would be reduced by only 20 per cent during that period.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet last Friday apparently 20 skillshare centres in Sydney were advised that their funding would be halved. That is a devastating blow for skillshare and those people who have given so much of their time to promote such a successful project. In my electorate of Barton, St George skillshare centre has had remarkable success. It assists 500 clients per year, and approximately 70 per cent of its trainees are placed in employment. It has a substantial client base and has brought together over 400 businesses in the area.

While one may think it is getting its support for altruistic reasons, that is not the case. Skillshare has delivered the goods. Business is benefiting from the high quality and character of trainees that emerge from the training. Skillshare is something which should be supported. The proof of the pie is in the eating. Skillshare has delivered the goods and any cuts are totally unjustified. It is something the government and the government members should well and truly get behind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to highlight the predicament of postal services to Christmas Island. I have just been advised that a particular postal service that was put in place to help Christmas Islanders has now been cancelled. That was a freight service operated by some parties from Perth to Jakarta. The postal freight was then flown from Jakarta to Christmas Island. That service has now ceased. At the moment, Ansett Airlines can only uplift between 400 and 500 kilos of post and freight from Perth to Christmas Island, leaving a shortfall of over 1,000 kilos per week required to sustain a level of service for the islanders.

SPEECH.PARA: My particular concern is that Stateships, which was operating into Christmas Island 18 months or so ago, has now stopped operating. Ansett Airlines provide a level of freight service, but unfortunately they cannot help Australia Post out to a level beyond 400 to 500 kilos a week.

National Jet is now flying from Broome into Christmas Island, and I am hoping that some kind of arrangement can be made between the Australian postal services and National Jet to get the post to Christmas Island. (Time expired)

The Deputy Prime Minister suggested that, indeed, I was speaking entirely about GATT when I said we had the opportunity to renege on our obligations. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to bring to the attention of the House a disease called apple and pear fire blight. Fire blight is a bacterial disease of pome fruit which leads eventually to the death of the trees. The disease is well established in New Zealand, but at the moment Australia is disease free. New Zealand is now making its second application to import apples into Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This fire blight bacteria can spread as simply as by wind‐borne pollen and by bees. Australia's most common pome fruit varieties are most susceptible to fire blight. The Goulburn Valley, in my electorate of Murray, would be particularly devastated. We have the biggest pear crops, we have the canneries and we have the weather conditions which are suited to the spread of this bacterial disease. An outbreak of fire blight would put Australia—with some 5,000 tonnes of apples and pears worth $150 million at farm gate value and approximately $500 million at retail level—at major risk.

It is estimated that up to 50 per cent of Australia's apple and pear production would be lost if we got this disease imported with imported fruit. This would result in a 25 per cent reduction in the net return to apple growers and a 40 per cent reduction in the net return of pear growers. Added to this is the reduction in the wages and salaries of those employed on farms and by processors, together totalling some $53 million. The most serious consequence would be the loss of one of the two canneries in the Goulburn Valley. Let us hope that AQIS thinks very well and inquires very carefully during its assessments of the risk of the introduction of fire blight, because the future of the Goulburn and Murray valleys is at stake.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Skillshare and Special Intervention Programs for Literacy

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

Skillshare is already delivering these services. Let us not reinvent the wheel. Orange skillshare has funded 454 commencements this year. It has had 743, with 309 outcomes—142 per cent of target. DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENT HOUSE STAFF: MR BRIAN FLANAGAN

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Treasurer. Did your pre‐election social security policy state that `under a coalition government the pension benchmark of at least 25 per cent of AWE will be maintained'? Did the Prime Minister on radio 2GB on 19 April say:

QUESTION.PARA: Now we are not going to muck around with the levels of pensions or their automatic indexation.

If you are not going to muck around with the levels of pensions, why did your deputy secretary write to the National Commission of Audit on 16 April saying that the Prime Minister, Treasurer and Minister for Finance had met. They suggested that the 25 per cent of AWE issue be considered by the NCA and that `in particular the ministers wanted the NCA to examine which particular measure of AWE was the most appropriate'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it entirely clear, as I have already, that the National Commission of Audit has done valuable work in reporting to the government. The govern ment does not automatically accept every recommendation that it makes. The government decides its own policy. The government reserves that right and the government always will. The government will be making policy decisions.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me also say that we are not afraid of information. We are not afraid of raising issues. Let me commend the work of the National Commission of Audit in relation to the medium and long term. Every now and then it is important in politics to look further than Christmas. In relation to the demographic changes, they have had a look at a number of factors which a government—any government—will have to face up to. The important thing is that every now and then a sober assessment is made to the public so that the public knows the situation that the Commonwealth finds itself in.

Unhappily, the situation that the Commonwealth finds itself in is very much the worse as a result of your maladministration over the last 13 years—very much the worse. It is very much the worse because you proposed to run deficit after deficit, about $70 billion to $80 billion of deficits since 1990‐91—about $70 billion of underlying deficit after 19 quarters of economic growth. Nothing could be more a testament to your maladministration and failure. It is important that the Australian public is given the truth and we welcome the opportunity of the National Commission of Audit to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister seen reports in recent days that the government may alter the method for calculating pensions in Australia? Are these reports accurate? What action is the government taking to ensure that those most in need, including many pensioners in my electorate, continue to have genuine assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the honourable member's question is yes. Could I also take this opportunity to inform her and the Australian public that the commitments made by the coalition in relation to the maintenance of indexation arrange ments, the commitments made in relation to the benchmark before the election, will be adhered to in full by the Howard government.

ANSWER.PARA: There will be no mucking around with pension levels. There will be no taking away of the social security safety net. I want to say to the Australian Labor Party: if you imagine for a moment that you are going to get some kind of political mileage out of any punitive destruction of the social security safety net by the new coalition government, you are absolutely 100 per cent dead wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer, and it follows both the Leader of the Opposition's question and the Prime Minister's reply just made. I seek further clarification from the Treasurer. Has the National Commission of Audit reported to you that to adopt a pensions benchmark in terms of total average weekly earnings rather than, as at present, male average weekly earnings would involve a reduction in payouts of some 15 per cent? Are you aware that translates into a saving for Commonwealth expenditure of some $5½ billion a year? Have you seen the further audit commission recommendation that adopting this definition `could remove a source of pressure on the government to raise pensions in the near future'? I ask the Treasurer: will you unequivocally now commit the government for the life of this parliament to not only not reducing pension levels but also continuing to raise pensions to the extent necessary to meet the existing benchmark of 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings?

—It was a long speech but the question has already been asked and answered on this side of the House. The Prime Minister has just said unequivocally that it was the policy of this government not to change the formula in relation to the calculation of pensions. It was asked on this side of the House. It was answered on this side of the House. It is a shame you did not bring your questions up to date.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: National Commission of Audit: Charter of Budget Honesty

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House what recommendations the National Commission of Audit made in relation to budget honesty across the government? What is the Treasurer's response to these recommendations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Commission of Audit has made far-reaching recommendations in relation to financial accounting by the Commonwealth. It recommends that legislation be introduced by government to set and report clear fiscal strategy with targets and benchmarks. It would make the government responsible for actually releasing to the public on a twice yearly basis up-to-date and comprehensive reports on fiscal and economic outlook at budget time, at the time of the mid-year review and immediately before elections. The fiscal reporting legislation would also require identification of discretionary policies intended to smooth the economic cycle.

ANSWER.PARA: The disgraceful concealment of the true position of the Commonwealth accounts before the last election has made it entirely necessary that legislation be put in place to allow a situation where the public is brought fully up to date with the information held by a government before an election. What happened in relation to the 1996 election, the concealment by the then Minister for Finance and others, should never be allowed to happen again. The only way in which that can be done is by legislation which forces by law a government to disclose the kind of information that was held by the Labor government prior to 2 March 1996.

Requiring the disclosure of that information will be in the interests of not only oppositions but governments too. The biggest winners, however, will be the people of Australia. The people of Australia deserve by law to have accurate financial accounting. They deserve to know the starting position in relation to all matters that are put before them at an election. In relation to the information that will be crucial to them in making their decisions, they deserve to be let in.

BREAK.PARA: Let me make it clear on behalf of this government that we will never allow to occur again the kind of concealment that Labor practised prior to the 2 March 1996 election. We will be introducing a charter of budget honesty. We will be very interested to know whether the now opposition will support those efforts to make financial accounting transparent and open.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a further question for the Treasurer, which also seeks clarification. I refer to the Prime Minister in his Radio 2GB interview on 19 April saying that `we're not going to . . . muck around with the levels of pensions or their automatic indexation'. Have you seen the proposal of the audit commission for `pension and other benefits being adjusted only on the basis of regular reviews in light of all relevant circumstances, including budget pressures'? Will you unequivocally commit the government for the life of this parliament to continuing the present practice of twice yearly automatic indexation? If you reckon this question has already been answered by you and the Prime Minister, notwithstanding the equivocation and the ducking and weaving, all you have to do is get up and say yes. That is all you have to do if that question has already been answered. Away you go—just say yes. They are three letters—y-e-s.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only do you practice repeating your questions over and over again, apparently you are going to practice trying to give the answers over and over again. The Prime Minister has already made it entirely clear, so let me put it simply so you can understand it. The Prime Minister has said here, regardless of the number of questions you have already put on your preordained question sheet, that this government will not by playing around with the formula, that it will be keeping the formula and that it will be maintaining the value of the pensions. There is no other way of expressing it. It should be clear even to you.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister and I have made it clear that the Commission of Audit has looked at alternatives but, as I made entirely clear at the time, this is a report to the government, not a report by the government. This is a government that will be making its policies. This is a government which will be announcing its position, and it has.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the minister received the Sherman report on the deaths of Australian‐based journalists in East Timor in 1975? If so, what steps does the government propose to take to make the report public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The government has received a report, prepared by Mr Tom Sherman, into the deaths of Australian journalists in East Timor in 1975. We are in the process of considering that report. This inquiry was established by the previous Minister for Foreign Affairs, and Mr Sherman has interviewed a large number of people in preparing his report.

ANSWER.PARA: I received the report on Friday, 21 June, and I would like to inform the House that there is in fact only one report; there are not two reports. There are not a secret report and a public report; there is just the one report. I will be tabling that one report in this chamber on Thursday after we have done two things: first, completed our own evaluation of the report and our own response to it and, secondly and appropriately, taken the opportunity to discuss the report with the next of kin. This report will not be kept from anybody; it will be made fully public. It is a comprehensive report. It is a very considered report. Others will be able to make their judgment about it as well as we as a government shall.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Treasurer. Is the Treasurer aware, given the undertakings that he has just made, that the Department of Social Security briefed the government when they came into office that the maintenance of that undertaking that he has just given would add $643 million in 1997‐98 to your bottom line and $973.7 million in 1998‐99 to your bottom line beyond any particular task that you have set yourself over the next little while? Do you still in those circumstances maintain your absolute commitment to all elements of the promises that you have just made?

—For about the fourth time, let us make it entirely clear that the government will be keeping the current arrangements which fix the level of pensions. If the Leader of the Opposition wants to make that point, let me make it entirely clear what the consequence is. You are apparently saying that the forward estimates provided by you did not make full allowance for the indexation of the pension, which means that you were not going to guarantee the formula. That can be the only conclusion. If the forward estimates do not have it in, then you have uncovered your own secret plot to breach indexation and the formula. Never before have I seen someone dig a hole and walk into it—and it was a big hole. That can be the only conclusion, and if you want a debate on that basis bring on the debate.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that the government's commitment to sell one‐third of Telstra has been endorsed by the Telstra board and its chief executive, Mr Blount? Is it a fact that Mr Blount has given an unequivocal undertaking that a partially privatised Telstra will deliver a higher quality of service and better value to its customers? Is this one of the major reasons why the government is committed to selling one‐third of Telstra?

—It is a fact that the Managing Director of Telstra, Mr Blount, and the Telstra board have given a strong endorsement to the government's proposal to privatise one-third of Telstra. And that is hardly surprising because the experience around the world is that when you partially privatise Telcos you end up delivering a better customer service, that when you inject some private sector money into organisations like Telstra the customer benefits and that when you expose them to competition the taxpaying public benefits. That is the reason why the government is committed to selling one‐third of Telstra.

BREAK.PARA: We believe there will be enormous public benefits. We believe that you will have a far better customer provision. We know that the community service obligations can be maintained. I am amused to keep reading in the press that members of the opposition say that if you privatise one-third of Telstra you are going to take away the community service obligation, particular in rural Australia, yet the organisation that knows more about rural Australia than any collection of Labor politicians could ever hope to, the National Farmers Federation of Australia, has made it 100 per cent clear that the great majority of its members and supporters, the men and women on the land in Australia, believe that the partial privatisation of Telstra is very good policy.

What Frank Blount has done is to blow right out of the water this very weak argument about the privatisation of Telstra. What he has demonstrated is that it will give a higher quality and better value service for all Australians. It will deliver a more accountable and efficient Telstra through greater price scrutiny. There will be an increased ability to respond to investment and market opportunities. There will be better access to capital in an expanding communications market.

Of course, it is part and parcel of our proposal that the employees of Telstra be given privileged access to ownership of shares in the partially privatised company. That is something that Labor Party people and trade unions do not really like. They hate the idea that workers should have privileged access to shares in the companies that employ them because—heaven forbid—the workers might end up having a greater loyalty to the company than they do to the union to which they belong. And it would be absolutely shocking if that were to ever happen!

PARA.BREAK: Mr Blount has said—and bear in mind that he is the Managing Director of Telstra and was appointed to that position while the former government was in power; he was not appointed to that position by us—that he has given an `unequivocal undertaking that we will deliver a higher quality of service and better value to you, as a partially privatised company, without diminishing or compromis ing Telstra's proud record of community service'.

BREAK.PARA: He went on to say that Telstra would be enabled, because of the partial privatisation, to respond more quickly to investment opportunities and to align more comfortably with new private sector partners. So he goes on, and the list is almost endless. What it is is the latest piece of evidence that not only are the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats completely out of step with what has really happened in the telecommunications market over the last few years, but also they are being very hypocritical in relation to their past performance on privatisation.

We all know the multiple backflips with double pikes that they performed on the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. We all know how they were opposed to the sale of the Commonwealth Bank in the mid‐1980s when they said that former Labor prime ministers would spin in their graves if you thought about selling the Commonwealth Bank. They said they would only sell half of it; they promised to keep the other half—and in the end they sold the lot.

The truth is that, if the Labor Party had won the last election, they would be up here now extolling not the virtues of selling one-third of Telstra but the virtues of selling 100 per cent of Telstra. The real difference in the last election campaign between the Labor Party and the coalition parties—and the Australian people knew this—was that, if the Labor Party had won the election, it would have sold the lot, despite having denied it.

The fact is that we said we would sell a third; we won the election and we are committed to selling a third; it will advantage Telstra, it will advantage the Australian community; and, to boot, it will lay the economic foundation for the largest environmental expenditure in Australia's history. Despite all those benefits, incredibly and unbelievably, the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats still oppose the sale of one-third of Telstra.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pick up on the answer just given by the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister: if he believes that the Australian Democrats should follow Mr Blount's advice on privatisation, why has the government ignored Mr Blount's advice to charge for directory assistance?
—Is that your policy, is it? This is the new Labor Party policy, is it?
—No, we rejected it.
—Oh, you rejected it. He rejected it. Well, so do we.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Given the success of landcare and protecting our natural resources, what is the government doing to create opportunities for Aboriginal people to become involved in landcare activities on lands under their direct control?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Landcare has undoubtedly been something of a cultural revolution and a great success in Australia. There are now 2,500 landcare groups and 20,000 active members. But one area that is often overlooked is that some 16 per cent of Australia's land surface is under Aboriginal control or management. Degradation of soil and water resources is evident on quite a few of those lands, and flora and fauna resources of natural significance are also at risk on some of those lands.

ANSWER.PARA: Landcare activity is presently, it has to be said, a relatively low priority for many Aboriginal communities, given that health, housing and education tend to dominate their concerns. Nonetheless, it has been recognised that landcare is integral for the future viability of communities as a whole. So threats posed by pressure from land uses which are beyond the capacity of resources to sustain as well as by major weed and feral animal infestations could lead to problems unless early action is taken to ensure improved resource management.

Contemporary Aboriginal land management is quite complex as a matter of fact, particularly where multiple uses are envisaged. So I am quite pleased to be able to announce that shortly a network of nine Aboriginal landcare facilitators is to be established. The aim will be to increase awareness of Aboriginal land management throughout the whole community, including the value and importance of traditional knowledge and practice.

It is envisaged that improved land management will be achieved through awareness raising, education, training, demonstration, and by assisting to identify problems and solutions. We need to recognise too that face-to-face communication is particularly important for Aboriginal people. This is recognised, as too are the close spiritual and cultural affinity that Aboriginal people have with land.

In conclusion, a greater involvement of indigenous women and youth will be sought in land management and landcare. In the past, land management decisions in relation to Aboriginal lands have often been made by administrators and not the traditional owners, subsequently frequently with very poor results. I am confident that this new initiative, which has the full support of stakeholders and representative groups, will lead to valuable long-term benefits to Australian lands as well as to the communities which depend on them.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: National Commission of Audit: Death Taxes

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Will the minister rule out immediately the recommendation of the National Commission of Audit to provide `scope to recover nursing home benefits from the estates of clients'—in other words, a death tax on nursing home residents. That is what it is; read the report.
—Perhaps the member did not hear me last time I responded to this question. I have responded most strongly to this, that the coalition has never supported death taxes.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Has the minister seen reports that tests may be introduced to ascertain the mental fitness of applicants for gun licences? Given the need for this issue to be handled sensitively and given the fact that there are important questions of privacy involved, what action is the government taking in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. The overwhelming majority of people who have a mental illness pose no threat to themselves or anybody else. However, there is some evidence that certain specific types of mental illness may in fact pose an increased risk. Predominantly I refer here to people with paranoid states, people who have not complied with medication, or people who have a history of drug abuse associated with mental illness. Therefore, to get further information, there is a cabinet subcommittee looking specifically at whether or not there are certain behavioural conditions that might be indicators of increased aggression and whether any policy action is warranted in this area, especially in relation to firearms.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a complex area subject to much misconception. Because of this I have commissioned a group of experts who I hope will be giving an interim report by the end of this month. I should say, though, in relation to those reports that the government is not looking at introducing the types of personality tests speculated about over the weekend. I cannot see how such tests could possibly work. Nor are we proposing a register of persons with mental illness. There has been very substantial progress in recent years in greater community tolerance of people with mental illness, and I would not want to see anything that increased the stigma associated with mental illness.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery the Lieutenant Governor of Victoria, Sir James Gobbo. On behalf of all honourable members, I extend you a very warm welcome to both Canberra and the parliament.
—Hear, hear!

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: National Commission of Audit: Higher Education

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Voca tional Education and Training. I refer to the recommendation of the National Commission of Audit that higher education be funded through `a fixed number of scholarships . . . redeemable at any accredited institution'. How is this different from your Fightback vouchers plan? Will you rule out such a plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is noting the recommendations of the audit commission that the Commonwealth retain responsibility for higher education and that university funding be undertaken by way of scholarships to students. In relation to the first of those recommendations, the Commonwealth already has effective responsibility for universities and there is certainly no intention to change that. In relation to the scholarship application recommendation, while the principle of contestability between institutions has some merit, the government notes that there is already a high level of competition between universities for staff and students.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me also make it clear that the government is concerned to ensure that any financing arrangements enhance equity of access for students from low income backgrounds and students from regional and rural areas. We are also concerned that any funding arrangements address the importance of mature age entry to universities. We are considering options for university funding but the proposed scheme, in our view, does not address a number of these issues in the form in which it is presented in the report, and the government has no plans to switch to a scholarship scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. I ask the minister: is the current system of review of immigration decisions satisfactory? Is the government addressing this issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Petrie for her question. As a preface to my answer, I note that this is refugee week. I will answer this question in the context of that. I want to affirm that this government maintains, as have governments before, a strong commitment to assisting bona fide refugees. Of course Australia has been very generous in a number of ways in ensuring that people who have been displaced and persecuted are resettled in Australia. It has had a very active program of support for those people who have very heavy requirements for support in Australia. Those who have suffered torture and trauma, in particular, have a heavy need for support when they come here to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: It is in this context I think that we need to look at the way in which some people come to Australia and seek to advantage themselves by accessing programs that are there for those who have particular needs. There are a large number of people who enter Australia illegally. Many more come here outlining circumstances such as a bona fide visit leading to them being able to access Australia. Then of course they seek to stay here, often not advancing any claims for protection but simply wanting to access a system that enables them to press claims that are not bona fide.

The situation we have at the moment is in no way satisfactory. My department is involved at the moment in something of the order of 559 cases before the courts and the numbers are steadily increasing. Sixty per cent of that workload relates to applications for asylum here in Australia. They have been made by people who have primarily come here illegally or who have misled us as to their intention when they have come to Australia. Last year my department spent something of the order of $60 million in financing detention and processing procedures in relation to this very large number of people. This amounts to a very significant proportion of my department's total budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixty million dollars?

—Sixty million dollars for dealing with detention, processing, defending cases before the courts and paying asylum seeker assistance. It is a situation which distorts our priorities and limits our ability to help those who are most vulnerable.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1989 the Immigration Review Tribunal was set up. In 1994 the Refugee Review Tribunal was set up. They were to provide independent merits review. The fact is that since that time litigation, which was then very prevalent, has not decreased but increased. So we now have a multi‐tier system for dealing with these matters. We keep people in detention very often while they pursue every entitlement that they believe under our system of law they are entitled to press.

The great majority are not able to found a claim which engages our protection obligations. Those who do are primarily assessed either through my department's consideration of these matters or through the independent merits review system. I think the number it actually established before the courts as having an entitlement for protection were four. A situation which occasions such significant costs and which does not serve our need of assisting the most vulnerable and certainly limits our capacity to be able to provide resources to assisting those who have needs cannot be allowed to go on.

I am certainly reviewing that system. I hope to be able to bring forward in the next sittings recommendations which will ensure that these are addressed and that we have an effective merits review system, but one which does not provide further access to judicial review which occasions such difficulties for the people involved. In relation to these matters, I am sure that the opposition will want to support us on those measures because this is an area in which we have been able to achieve bipartisan support over time—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had that decisions report which was published last year.

—That is one matter, but I would talk that matter through with you because I suspect that if you take it out of the area of speciality you are more likely to get a great disparity of decision making by individuals who have very little experience in dealing with these matters and you then have to have access to the courts to try to bring it together. My own view is that you have to have specialist bodies that are able to offer consistent decisions and do not introduce variations that then have to be sorted out by the courts and provide justification for it.

ANSWER.PARA: This is an area in which I invite the cooperation of the opposition because if we fail in relation to dealing with these questions many more people will seek to come here and the costs that we have seen to date will be small in comparison.

—I made the point in the answer that the shadow minister refers to that in my meetings I had not had these representations made to me.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting—

I am happy to check my records in relation to any other conversations I have had, but I certainly have no recollection whatsoever of foreign ministers or presidents raising this issue with me. The simple point is that it is not a matter of deep contention in our bilateral relationships.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House whether the government intends to take any action to remove this uncertainty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it back; I withdraw.
