TALK.START.PARA: —We will try again. My question this time is also addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the public statement by the Chinese ambassador in Canberra that your decision to axe aid projects to be funded by DIFF will cause significant financial losses for China and `do no good to the Australian side' in terms of our credibility and business interests. Can the minister tell the House how Australia's business interests in China were advanced by his denial in this House last Tuesday, contrary to the facts, that he had not received any representation from Chinese ministers concerning the axing of DIFF? Was it not a fact that in the letter from Vice Minister Sun, Vice Minister Sun made it clear that he is writing on his own behalf and on behalf of Minister Wu? Is it also a fact that your acknowledgment and reply on 29 May, the following month, makes that absolutely clear—that it was a ministerial representation? Can I conclude by asking: what is the minister's response to the fact that the letters exchanged between the minister and the vice minister of the Chinese ministry of foreign trade and economic cooperation concerning DIFF were actually leaked from the Chinese embassy in Canberra on the day after your answer last Tuesday? Doesn't that fact demonstrate that the contemptuous dismissal of the serious concerns of the Chinese government has actually caused great damage to our bilateral relations, damage which prompted the Chinese embassy to take action when you lied to this parliament?
—Look at this.
—The honourable member for Batman knows that newspapers are not allowed in the House—you know that. I ask the shadow minister to withdraw the word `lied'.
—When he misled the parliament.
—I ask the shadow minister to withdraw both the word `lie' and `misled', two separate—
—I do so; I withdraw.
—Both comments have been withdrawn.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I frankly would have thought that if anything did damage to Australia's standing with China it was the shadow minister for foreign affairs going around claiming that the Chinese embassy is an embassy full of leakers; that apparently they leak documents. Frankly, I am astounded that you would say something like that and, yet again, do some damage to Australia's standing.

ANSWER.PARA: It is absolutely true: I did get this letter from the vice minister and, as I explained in answer to the previous question, I replied to the letter from the vice minister. When I sought advice from my department as to the status of the vice minister in order to clarify the record here—which I am quite happy do to do—my department advised me that he was a departmental secretary equivalent. It is hard to make these comparisons but, given that he was not a minister of the equivalent status of some of those who sit along here on this front bench, it seemed to me a perfectly clear point.

The suggestion from the Labor Party that somehow the whole of the edifice of our relationship with China under them, under your government, depended on a soft loan scheme is simply an astounding proposition. As I said earlier, if this were such an extraordinarily important point in our bilateral relationship with China, then surely you would expect the Chinese foreign minister to have raised it with our ambassador. You would expect that; you would expect that if it was something he was so deeply concerned about it. The simple fact is that he did not.

BREAK.PARA: Of course government officials from governments which will no longer receive DIFF funding have discussed these issues with my officials. The fact that government officials discuss these things is inevitable. Maybe they report to their ministers on what they do, and surely they do. But it is a far cry from saying that the Chinese foreign minister has written to me, or come to me, and expressed fundamental concern about this issue, which of course he would do if it were a vitally important issue in our bilateral relationship.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Parkes for his question. The current government places a great deal of importance on small business. In fact, the Prime Minister, during the election campaign, described small business as the engine room of the Australian economy. Small business generally feels quite disappointed after 13 years of neglect by those sitting opposite. We intend to, and have, put in place many positive programs to assist the small business community.

ANSWER.PARA: The deregulation task force set up by this government met in Canberra, and then last Friday in Melbourne. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the member for Kingsford‐Smith moving forthwith that this House censures the Minister for Foreign Affairs for:
(1) having wilfully misled the House and the Australian people in his statement of 18 June 1996 concerning regional responses to the axing of the Development Import Finance Facility; and
(2) having demonstrated by his disgraceful action that he is not fit to hold the high office of Minister for Foreign Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

—Ministers must be honest in their public dealings and should not intentionally mislead the parliament or the public. Any misconception caused inadvertently should be corrected at the earliest opportunity. But what has happened in this case? Does the Leader of the Opposition accept this censure?
—He is seeking leave; we gave leave before. Move your motion then we can have your silly debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Minister for Foreign Affairs for:
(1) having wilfully misled the House and the Australian people in his statement on 18 June concerning regional responses to the axing of the Development Import Finance Facility; and
(2) having demonstrated by his disgraceful action that he is not fit to hold the high office of Minister for Foreign Affairs.

As all members of the House will be aware, the most solemn duty imposed upon a minister of the Crown under the Westminster system is to be truthful and to be candid to the parliament and to the country. These were the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) himself when, as Deputy Leader of the Opposition, nearly 13 years ago he moved the first motion of censure against a minister in the then Labor government. The Prime Minister reaffirmed that appropriately high standard when on 2 April this year he issued guidelines on ministerial responsibility which include the vitally important rule:
Ministers must be honest in their public dealings and should not intentionally mislead the parliament or the public. Any—
and this is terribly important—
misconception caused inadvertently should be corrected at the earliest opportunity.

It is in the light of the evidence that has come to hand that I have moved this very serious censure motion this afternoon—the first censure motion the opposition has moved against the government. Our attitude has been that we should not be moving, as they did, censure motion after censure motion; that it should be reserved for the most serious of cases. We determined that only when there was absolute evidence in a very clear case would we use this in the parliament. But the charge of misleading parliament is one of the most grave that can be levelled against any minister. It is not a charge that should be made lightly—and we do not do so.

There is an additional, crucial dimension in this particular case. The subject of this motion is the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer)—the man who represents our country overseas; the man who is indeed the diplomatic face of Australia; the man who speaks on behalf of our nation at international fora; the man whose word must be absolutely believable to our friends and to our neighbours.

What we have before us today is an open and shut case. There are no ifs; there are no buts. There is no opportunity to wriggle off the hook. The facts speak for themselves. Last Tuesday I asked a perfectly straightforward question of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I asked him whether he could confirm that China, Indonesia, the Philippines and Vietnam had all made official protests against the government decision to axe development projects to be funded by the DIFF scheme.

I pointed out in that question last Tuesday that the Chinese ambassador in Canberra had stated publicly that the axing of DIFF would `do no good to the Australian side in terms of our credibility and business interests'. I asked whether it was not the case that the Chinese government had made at least four representations at vice ministerial level. That was my question. The foreign minister's reply was—what can I say?—the reply of a petulant schoolboy.

It is not just the tone of his performance last Tuesday that is a problem. We now have in a foreign minister someone who is an embarrassment to this House and, worse still, someone charged with the responsibility of representing our nation overseas.
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not what is before us today. The issue is what he said in answer to that question. He said, in his contemptuous dismissal, that there had been no repeated protests at a ministerial level. Indeed, he dismissed out of hand the question of Indonesia, Vietnam, the Philippines or even China having protested about DIFF. He told the House—and it is very important that we go to his specific words:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that of course some officials—
and today he is equating officials with vice ministers, and my question was about vice ministers—
who are involved in the details of these programs have raised issues of these programs with my department, and you would not expect otherwise.
But—
and these are the words that hang him—
if this was a serious issue in our relationships they would raise it at the ministerial level.
They were the minister's words. He went on to say:
They would be writing me letters.
Opposition members interjecting—They were!
They would be expressing their concerns to me.
Then he said this:
There has been not one raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—I will say it is not true. They were his words:

SPEECH.PARA: They would be writing me letters. They would be expressing their concerns to me. There has been not one raised.
With those words, the foreign minister flagrantly and disgracefully misled this House.

The facts are these: on 24 April Sun Zhenyu, the vice minister of the Chinese ministry MOFTEC, wrote to the Minister for Foreign Affairs on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation, Madam Wu Yi, a key minister in the Chinese government, and one whom we all know and respect immensely.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very, very nice person.

—They wrote to congratulate the foreign minister on his appointment. You will remember that I am sure, foreign minister. Do you remember the letter of congratulations? I am sure that you tucked it away, a file copy of it for your memoirs. Maybe you did not. After all, the Chinese did not waste much time on pleasantries when they wrote on 24 April. No, no, no; not at all. The vice minister got straight down to business when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We now send this letter to you regarding the DIFF program matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —`We'? `We sent'!

—`We', yes. He is writing on behalf of Minister Wu and himself. Mr Speaker, I am reading from a translation of the vice minister's letter. But I have checked it, and I am assured that it is a very good translation, one that captures the essential nuance of the letter. It is a good translation from exactly the document that the minister held in his hands when he read the views of the Chinese government. He read them and he responded to them on 29 May.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what the Chinese government had to say. I know all honourable members should listen very carefully to the words of the vice minister, writing on behalf of the Chinese minister of MOFTEC, who said:

BREAK.PARA: There has been Sino Australian Government soft loan cooperation initiated since 1988. In the past few years with effort by both governments this cooperation has gradually expanded and achieved satisfactory results. Up until now the joint cooperative soft loan projects total over 60 with the turnover reaching US $540 million. The completion of these projects has reinforced our infrastructure establishment and environmental protection and the living standards of the poor areas of our country have been improved, positive effects have been produced.
The letter refers to the fact that DIFF has assisted Australian exporters to enter the Chinese market and that the scheme has proved beneficial to both countries. The vice minister's letter goes on:

For a long time AusAID has established a relationship of cooperation with my Ministry and that assured soft loan projects would be completed smoothly. But recently AusAID has been waiting for the new Government's policy that withhold the normal operations of soft loan projects, and for this we express our strong concern.

These people are not mincing words. This is right to the point. This is central to the whole DIFF debate. `We express our strong concern'—that is what the Chinese government had to say. That is what they said directly, that is what they said in writing to you as foreign minister for Australia. What did you say to the House last week? You said:

But if this was a serious issue in our relationships they would raise it at the ministerial level. They would be writing me letters. They would be expressing their concerns to me. There has been not one raised.
The vice minister's letter continued:

Because both sides on the agreed projects have invested a lot of man hours and capital if those projects cannot be started by the 30th of June this year it will cause the project companies on both sides a substantial financial loss.

That is what the Chinese government had to say to us. I believe that they said—you can understand this from the China side—that these companies taking these projects cannot wait any longer for uncertainties.
Some of those projects might have to be forced to seek the technology and equipment from other countries, particularly at the moment as Australian soft loan future is unclear.
The Chinese government said:
For the above stated reasons I hope your Government will give continuous support with the agreed listed projects so these projects can be executed on time.
They enclosed a list of the multitude of projects that were covered under the DIFF scheme.

It is little wonder that the Chinese government was enraged when the minister stood here in the parliament this week and said that no such representations had been made. So enraged were they that within 24 hours they had taken action to expose the minister's deceit. What an absolutely extraordinary state of affairs. Can you believe that this is happening so soon in the life of this government?

What does it say about the government's commitment to further develop our nation's engagement in Asia? Why did the minister do this? I think the answer is simple: his policy is indefensible. The axing of DIFF has been universally condemned. It has been condemned by Australian business organisations. It has been condemned by overseas aid organisations. It has been condemned by all our neighbouring governments. As one leading foreign policy commentator has described it, the decision is just `dumb, dumb, dumb'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ah, we were waiting for this!

—The Minister for Foreign Affairs has made no serious attempt to defend the merits of his decision. Instead, last week he and his parliamentary secretary first sought to shamelessly and disgracefully attack the integrity of a leading and authoritative critic of the decision, that is, Richard Woolcott.
—You are a liar. I never said that.
—Yes, you did. You gave him a serve. Of course you did.
—Order! Minister, withdraw.
—Yes, I withdraw.
—That, however, was not enough. What the Minister for Foreign Affairs then did was brazenly and disgracefully deceive this House. I ask that the minister withdraw that comment.
—The minister will withdraw.
—I said it.

—What the Minister for Foreign Affairs then did was to brazenly and disgracefully deceive this House about the strength of the regional response to the decision, to mislead this House about one fundamental issue, that is, his dealings on our behalf with foreign governments. That is what he stood here in the parliament and did in this chamber last week.

BREAK.PARA: The question that must be asked now is whether this man is fit to hold the high office of Minister for Foreign Affairs, whether he is a fit and proper person to represent our nation in our dealings with the region and the wider world. The answer to that question can only be a resounding no. No, he is not up to it. No, he is not fit for it.

I said this before and I repeat it now: this is an open and shut case. The minister has misled the parliament. In doing so, he has dealt a grave blow to public confidence in his government. This is in every sense a hanging offence. The 1976 report of the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, as quoted at page 88 of the House of Representatives Practice, says:

In cases where the minister has misled parliament, condoned or authorised a blatantly unreasonable use of executive power or, more vaguely, where the minister's behaviour contravenes established standards of morality, resignation or dismissal is the appropriate action.
Those are the rules, the rules that we all operate under. They are the rules that were drummed into all of us who have had the high honour of serving in a ministerial capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you resign then?

—Let there be absolutely no doubt about it: the minister has deceived this parliament. This is a minister who has deceived the Australian people. This is a minister who must resign. This is a minister who has got to go. If he is not prepared to go, the Prime Minister must sack him or, to use the words of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) on another occasion, he will forever wear the stain of shame that he was one who undermined the most fundamen tal principle of Westminster parliamentary democracy—
—Westminster!

—The principle that a minister must account to the parliament; the principle that, whatever else, a minister must never mislead the parliament. I have had the honour of serving in a ministerial capacity in two parliaments in Australia. The first lesson that was read to me by the then Premier of New South Wales many, many years ago—
—Why didn't you listen to it?

—It was, `You don't have to answer the question in any way other than you see fit, but you must never tell a lie.' That is what the Premier said: `You must never mislead the parliament knowingly—or, indeed, unknowingly—because that is a hanging offence. In respect of an opportunity where you mislead the parliament unknowingly, you must take immediate steps to come to the parliament to rectify the situation, to set the record straight.'

BREAK.PARA: What we have seen from the minister today, unbelievably—having shot himself between the eyes—is him destroying his only potential defence. He has admitted here in question time, too smart by half again, that he checked his answer and his officers told him what had occurred, told him that he had misinformed the parliament. But he did not come into this chamber and correct the record. Why, I ask the House, did he not do so?

TALK.START.PARA: —Arrogance.

—Was it arrogance, or was it to do with the fact that his parliamentary secretary, within a few minutes of his misleading the parliament, elaborated on the minister's earlier reference to Richard Woolcott and said that he challenged Richard Woolcott's integrity. Was that the reason that you did not come into the parliament and correct the record? Or was it the fact that you were bogged down, denying that you recalled anything of the public controversy in 1992 about the leaked report from 1988 of Miles Kupa, which your ministerial colleague in the other place, Senator Hill, said would do Australia grave damage and bring grave offence in Indonesia. This is at the time that you were the shadow minister for trade, working in the same area. Were they the two reasons you did not come into the parliament and correct the record? We will, perhaps, never know.

BREAK.PARA: I say to the House: there is no alternative in this situation. The Prime Minister has to sack this foreign minister if he is not prepared to go. If the Prime Minister does not sack him, for whatever reason, it will be an appalling abrogation of the standards to which he professes to adhere, the standards that he made such great play of in the lead-up to the last election and immediately after the election, the standards that the government set itself. If the Prime Minister does not sack him, it will mean that ministers will be above reproach for their conduct and for all their statements in this House. That is a totally unacceptable situation under the Westminster system. It will give Mr Speaker a green light from here on for ministers to mislead this parliament, and to do so with impunity. That is what a failure to dismiss this minister will mean. It will mean that, on simple matters of fact, ministers will be able to stand up in this parliament and say that black is white and that white is black, and they will be allowed to get away with it.

If that ever becomes permissible, this House may as well forget about question time. We may as well forget about the Westminster system. We may as well forget about the system and its standards that we cherish. It will become a sham, and the Prime Minister will wear the stain of shame for the rest of his prime ministership.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have the opportunity to engage in a debate with the member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton). But it does not become the member for Kingsford‐Smith to be moving a motion challenging other people's integrity. If ever there was a minister in the previous government who was discredited and dishonest, it was the member for Kingsford-Smith. He was one of the most discredited politicians that this country has ever known. Everything he touched turned to stone.

SPEECH.PARA: You would have to admit, Mr Speaker, that the third runway fiasco was a matter of profound embarrassment to the previous government. There was the complete catastrophe of the third runway, with flight paths being varied to the benefit of the electorate of the member for Kingsford-Smith. How much integrity was there in that? What about the way the Australian National Line was managed? The member for Kingsford-Smith said, `We can't give it away,' and then engaged in some exercise of trying to sell it. Look at the way the member for Kingsford-Smith managed the Australian National Railways.

The fact is that everything you touched went broke. You really were a minister who could only be described as totally incompetent. The point is that you have repeated the performance this afternoon. So do not interject too enthusiastically before you know the facts. Never take the facts from Laurie—never do it. That is the one warning I would give to the Labor Party: never take Laurie as your guide. Don't ever do that. What are the facts in this particular case? The facts are that—

TALK.START.PARA: —You misled the House. That is the fact.

—You do not want to hear the facts. Mr Sun Zhenyu, who is the Chinese vice minister, did indeed write me a letter—the shadow minister is quite right—and indeed I did write back, but I had the decency to check what position a vice minister is in the context of our system. I said in question time that the position of vice minister was the equivalent of the position of secretary. That was the advice I received from my department last week, and I now have further advice which I have just received during this debate. The further advice is that there is above the vice minister the position of first vice minister. The first vice minister is the equivalent of a secretary, and Vice Minister Sun Zhenyu is the equivalent of a deputy secretary in our system.

PARA.BREAK: I am not trying to belittle this. I would have been very happy to have come back to the House to correct the record, and I always will be. I will go through all the files this after noon and make sure that the statement is completely correct and, if anything needs to be corrected, I will correct it. But I will not be correcting this, because this bloke is the equivalent of a deputy secretary and you are trying to claim this is Madam Wu, who is the relevant minister. She is the equivalent of our minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Never let it be forgotten that the shadow minister, the member for Kingsford‐Smith, in one of his first exercises in party politics in opposition, has himself already committed quite a significant gaffe by coming into this parliament and telling everybody in this parliament that the Chinese embassy leaks material to him! I have to say that was a most extraordinarily foolish thing to have done. That will be bitterly resented by the Chinese embassy, and I do not doubt they will be happy to talk to you about that. Whether they are the equivalent of deputy secretaries or secretaries—or whatever positions they hold—I am sure they will be happy to hear that the shadow minister for foreign affairs came into this parliament on a political stunt and took the opportunity to accuse the Chinese embassy of leaking. What an extraordinary thing to have done!

While the member for Kingsford‐Smith was making his speech, members of the Labor benches, including the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), were making all sorts of derisory remarks about Madam Wu's name. I do not think that is helpful. I do not think that helps. No wonder you people were expunged from office. No wonder you were. One of the things about the Labor Party today is not only that you still have not woken up to the fact that you lost the election but also that you have never asked yourselves why you lost the election. You have never bothered to ask yourselves that question. There is this constant boasting about the brilliance of your foreign policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I want you to ask the minister to withdraw that reflection—
—What is your point of order?
—My point of order is that nobody on this side of the House was reflect ing on Madam Wu, and it is completely out of order—
—There is no point of order. Resume your seat.

—When it comes to integrity, I have to say that the Labor Party's record on overseas aid is a record that stands tall because of its lack of integrity. The member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) knows this only too well. Remember before the 1983 election campaign. The then minister responsible for the overseas aid program expressly promised to lift the level of aid during the life of the 1993‐96 parliament from 0.36 per cent to 0.4 per cent. Remember that? In 1993 you promised to lift aid to 0.4 per cent of GNP. Did you lift aid from 0.36 per cent to 0.4 per cent of GNP? No. You reduced it to 0.33 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Why did you do that? Why did you go to the electorate and say you would lift the aid vote and then, three years later, reduce it? Why did you do that? To have the cheek to come in here and accuse a minister of misleading the House!

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not true and you know it. Answer the question.

—Absolutely! You accuse me. This man who wrote to me is the equivalent of a deputy secretary. Weak! Very weak! Very weak indeed! You are the people who made a promise to the Australian electorate before the 1993 election and you flagrantly broke it. What did you do about foreign aid during the last election campaign? What did you do then? You repeated the promise, didn't you, Gary? You repeated the promise you made in 1993. You went along on 23 February and you said in a prepared speech that Labor would increase aid from 0.33 per cent to 0.4 per cent by the year 2000, didn't you? And, when a spokesman in your office was asked whether that was a commitment, your spokesman said, `Yes, it is a commitment.'

SPEECH.PARA: There it was, all over the newspapers, that you had made this commitment. All the aid groups believed you had made a commitment. But what happened? We actually sat down and costed your commitment. Increasing aid from 0.33 per cent to 0.4 per cent would have blown out your budget by another $1 billion. You would have a $9 billion black hole now if you or the then Prime Minister had not got on to the phone to Gary and said to him, `Look, let's walk away from this commitment. It's not a commitment. We have decided it is an aspiration.' So we went from a commitment to an aspiration. Whether that was done by a phone call from the Prime Minister history will never record, but the fact is that the then minister switched his commitment and we had a completely new aid promise. The $1 billion aid hole was simply a matter of serious embarrassment.

Let me conclude by saying that, when it comes to integrity in foreign policy, these people have very little to boast about. The member for Kingsford‐Smith raises the question about Indonesia. Don't forget what happened last year with the Mantiri affair. Let the House know this: what happened was that the Indonesians asked the Australian government whether they would give agreement for General Mantiri to become the ambassador to Australia. The submission went from the department to the then Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, Gordon Bilney. The submission recommended that, in spite of the comments General Mantiri had made—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know you don't want to hear this, but I think the House might be interested. General Mantiri had made these remarks on East Timor, but the submission recommended that the agreement be given to the Indonesian government.

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs Crosio interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Prospect!

—The acting minister gave his agreement. He approved that, didn't he? When the then Minister for Foreign Affairs came back to Australia—or back to work—he wrote on that submission `Noted.' So he agreed with it as well. The then Australian government told the Indonesian government, `Yes, you can have your General Mantiri as the ambassador to Australia,' and then went into a panic and tried to change the whole agreement.

BREAK.PARA: In effect, you abrogated an agreement you had already made with the Indonesian government. I have left this till last, because there is one person in this House who stands out above all others when it comes to the abrogation of agreements. It is the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith; you are the bloke who, days before the airline agreement with New Zealand was due to come into force, sent a fax to Morris Williamson, the New Zealand Transport Minister—or was it to Don McIven?—saying, `We have decided to rip up the agreement.' The Australian government made an agreement and then the Australian government ripped it up. You think making an agreement and ripping it up is lying? Yes, it is. You are a dishonest and dishonourable man for ripping up that agreement. You laugh about it. He thinks it is funny to rip up an agreement with the New Zealand government. Well, it is dishonest and dishonourable—that is what it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I would ask that those offensive remarks be withdrawn.
—It's a censure motion. On a point of order: it's a censure motion.
—What do you find specifically offensive?
—It's a censure motion.
—Hold on, hold on!
—`Dishonest and deceitful', I think were the words, Mr Speaker.
—I call the minister.
—The fact is that it was a woeful thing to do; it caused bitter resentment in New Zealand. The fact of the matter is that it did this country's reputation in New Zealand a good deal of damage.

BREAK.PARA: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me conclude with one more point, if I can make myself heard, Mr Speaker, and you can keep a bit of order. My point is this.
—You're a liar.
—The honourable member for Maribyrnong will withdraw that comment.
—A week or two ago, one of the members of this House made some allegation against another member for plagiarism.
—In deference to the chair, Mr Speaker—
—I want an unequivocal withdrawal.
—I withdraw.
—I warn the member for Prospect.

—The simple fact is that the member for Kingsford‐Smith himself is a plagiarist, because there was an article by Greg Sheridan, a Sydney journalist, and hours later in the day there was Laurie out having a doorstop, reiterating the exact lines from the article. Have a bit of imagination. Pick up your own arguments. Don't just drag them up from someone else: intellectually lazy, intellectually sloppy.

BREAK.PARA: It is not misleading the House to say that the equivalent of a deputy secretary has written me a letter and to then point out that that man does not have the status of a minister. He does not have the status of a minister. You have damaged our relations with China through your rash behaviour of accusing the Chinese embassy of leaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —This country paid a very high price for John Howard's peaceful acquisition of the leadership of the Liberal Party, because it set in train a course of events which gave us a lying buffoon for a foreign minister. That is precisely what that particular leadership contest produced.
—Mr Speaker, that is obviously unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.
—I ask the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw.

—I withdraw `lying'. It is a censure motion, but I withdraw `lying'. It gave us a deceitful, dishonest buffoon for a foreign minister, who has spent his time up here today doing nothing. Whatever else he has been doing here today, one thing he has not been doing is defending himself. The sole defence which he mounts now is a notion that somehow—

BREAK.PARA: Mr Fahey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think you should listen to this either, John, because it is embarrassing. He has humiliated your government. He has humiliated his Prime Minister (Mr Howard). He has set a set of standards now which mark that position that the Prime Minister adopted when he came into office and suggested that his ministers must never mislead and, if they inadvertently do so, they must immediately correct it.

BREAK.PARA: He has made an absolute nonsense of that. He has done you personally, as a minister, no credit at all. You must defend him because you do not wish to see him drift out in circumstances of extreme embarrassment to the government. I can understand why you would wish to absent yourself from this debate, and you ought to feel absolutely free to do so. I will not offer a critical remark if you or anyone else wants to move out of this place and not defend him. You will have to defend him when you come in for the vote but I suggest you all nick off because he is a major embarrassment to you.

Let us go to this piece of correspondence which he cheerfully ignores. His department, as he admitted in here today, sought to get him to correct himself. His department said, `Perhaps, sir, you may have inadvertently misled the House. Perhaps, sir, you may have been unaware of this correspondence.' The department did not hotfoot it over to advise him of this correspondence from the Chinese foreign ministry because they felt he perhaps needed a little additional information. They hotfooted it over, like any good department, to advise the minister that he had misled the House, to give the minister maximum opportunity to rise in this place and do the thing that ministers must do when that occurs—that is, immediately correct themselves.

The department was in that office really quickly because they knew exactly what was at stake. They knew exactly what was in the letter. They knew exactly what was in Alexander Downer's correspondence of only two weeks earlier. I will read the opening paragraph. The rest of the letter is a damning indictment of the government's cretinous policy on DIFF, so we will start out with the first paragraph. It is that first paragraph which reveals the true deceit of this man. It begins thus:
Honourable Minister—
as though people of no significance are the formal, first point of contact on a congratulatory piece of correspondence as well as that for issues being raised with a new minister coming in—
Firstly, congratulations to you on your appointment as Minister for Foreign Affairs and our Honourable Minister, Wu Yi would like me to send her best regards. We now . . .

One thing we can be absolutely certain of is that the vice minister is not royal. Therefore, when he uses the plural he is referring to someone else other than himself. Who does he refer to as someone else other than himself? A minister, Wu Yi. The letter continues:
We now send this letter to you regarding the DIFF programme matter.

The letter then goes on to detail to the minister over here the policy on behalf of the minister, under the instructions of the minister, and their protest at what has been the dishonest destruction of an important point of cooperation between us and what will be by the turn of this century, or shortly thereafter, the world's largest economy with which all will wish to trade. The letter says all of that. Then Alexander Downer, the foreign minister, replied to all of that, saying:
Dear Vice minister,
I would like to sincerely thank you, and Minister Wu Yi—
he sure as hell knew who was corresponding with him—

for your congratulatory message in your letter of 24 April 1996 on my appointment as Minister for Foreign Affairs. I would also like to thank you for writing and expressing your views about the Australia‐China Concessional Finance Facility (CFF).

There is absolutely no doubt whatsoever that it was thoroughly understood in the minister's office, in the department of foreign affairs, that they had on their hands a piece of ministerial correspondence. They were not out there wandering around just for the sake of completeness. If they had been doing that, they would have been straight over to him with a whole raft of correspondence that had been out there in the department from all those stations around Asia that had been receiving protests from governments at all levels about what had been going on with the DIFF program.

His department selected this because, on their best interpretation, he had inadvertently, they hoped, misled the House. We on this side of the House do not believe for one minute that he inadvertently misled the House. He will stand up and say anything in this chamber without the slightest concern for the veracity of it. He burbles on at the mouth and he gets himself and this country into trouble repeatedly. However, again in his burbling here, without realising that he had to adopt a sensitive defensive position, he realises now what this House must now consider: whether or not it was inadvertent that when he stood up to give his buffoon's answer to our shadow minister for foreign affairs he had sincerely forgotten his correspondence of three weeks prior to that date. He turned that inadvertence into a lie by his inaction from that point onwards.

He should take a look at the ministerial guidelines that his Prime Minister gave him when he came into office. The Prime Minister clearly anticipated such events. In his directions to Mr Downer, the Prime Minister said:

Ministers must be honest in their public dealings and should not intentionally mislead the Parliament or the public. Any misconception caused inadvertently should be corrected at the earliest opportunity.

It is quite possible that ministers with thousands of things on their plates will forget pieces of correspondence they have. They rarely, I might say, forget pieces of correspondence to other ministers but they will forget from time to time pieces of correspondence they have with other people. If they are very smart, they will never forget pieces of correspondence they have with China at whatever level. It is actually possible that these things will occur. When you get up there and say that you have not misled this place—and there have been three days of sittings since the department drew your attention to their view that you had inadver tently misled the House—whatever it was that you did last Tuesday, you have lied since.

You have failed to correct the error on your part. You have failed to come into this chamber and say, `I wish to add to my answer for the sake of completeness' or whatever weasel words you want to use—words that ministers from time to time use. You did not avail yourself of that opportunity, and you did not avail yourself of that opportunity for the most obvious of reasons.

This is a minister who is not concerned with standards. This is a minister who believes that he can skate around in any particular direction. Everything is light‐hearted. We are all having fun. We are all acting out some sort of P.G. Wodehouse Bertie Wooster event of the 1920s. The minister has this sort of belief about himself: it does not really matter what it is that you say in this place; the minister just gets up in this place and rattles on. But the simple fact of the matter is that, having put himself in this position, he has made a liar of his entire government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think the leader might withdraw the word `liar'.
—Gee, Mr Deputy Speaker, I have participated in a lot of censure debates in this place, and the word `liar' has been frequently used in them.
—Far too frequently.
—That word may have been far too frequently used but this is the one time you are allowed to use it. But if you call on me to withdraw, then I will withdraw it.
—Thank you.

—This deceitful man, who happens to hold the foreign ministry, has disgraced his office and his position. The reason why he did not correct his error is that he faces embarrassment on a multiplicity of fronts. His gaucheness, his ineptness in handling foreign affairs issues, has meant that on a whole plethora of fronts he now faces public criticism. It has come as a shock to him.

BREAK.PARA: It is a shock to him to sit there and see cartoons of himself in the paper with a bowl and chopsticks in front of him, and noodles all over his face. When he sees them, he finds them embarrassing and deeply depressing. Therefore, in that sort of atmosphere, having ticked them off, we have an incompetent selection—no, not incompetent because he is a good man; an ill-advised selection—in regard to an appointment in Indonesia; a number of embarrassments in relation to DIFF that are popping off all over the South-East Asian region; and an incompetent performance in recent times in dealing with our principal ally, the United States.

When you have a hat-trick running, you do not want to make it four wickets in four balls. What he was entitled to do was to move away from the hat-trick of being bowled out on the serious issues that confronted him to the record of four wickets in four balls. That is the last thing that he wanted to have apply to himself on this occasion. He is being mocked and ridiculed out there in the general public. But, worse than that for this country, he is being mocked and ridiculed everywhere around the region.

This government is on notice in the region around us. The former Prime Minister did not say that the countries of this region would not deal with this government. The countries of this region deal with polite people. The countries of this region consist of polite people. They believe that they can have a sensible conversation with whomever runs Australia, and they are prepared to put their points to them. In dealing with this country they do not regard themselves as dealing with a bunch of obtuse individuals. They believe that, when the advice of ministers on behalf of ministers is right, those ministers will get a bit of attention. They believe that we can deal with signals they send by both back channels and forward channels—because this is not a confrontationist region. This is not a region that shirtfronts you as a minister when you meet other ministers. That is not their way. That is not the way of this region.

But they make it amply clear to you that you know exactly what they mean in the sorts of correspondence that they enter into with you. The sort of correspondence that you got from the vice minister on behalf of the minister was precisely part of that sort of process. Of course the minister is not going to raise it with you. Of course the minister is not going to buttonhole you. The minister has had you written to at length and in detail about their country's objections to the policies that you have put in place. Then you responded at length and in detail to the complaints of the foreign minister that had been put before you.

The test that the former Prime Minister put to you was not whether or not you would be listened to but whether or not you would be capable of conveying a view; capable of putting a uniquely Australian position on the security and economic issues of this region; capable of dealing with the subtleties of the region; capable of promoting an Australian interest in an area in which—in terms of population, economics and power—we are very much a minority. This is a country where leaders have to be better than most—not `as good as most' but `better than most'. This is a country which must not only observe proprieties; it must know the signals and understand them.

The nickname of this gentleman when he was at school about 20 years ago—but some would think it only 18 months ago—was `Dodger'. We now see the reason why that was so: Dodger Downer by name, Dodger Downer by nature. He has dodged the Prime Minister's position on propriety. He has humbled the Prime Minister's position on propriety. He has set a low standard for the observance of the Prime Minister's position on propriety. He should be censured because he is disgraced. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr SHARP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we are, the first sitting day after the release of the National Audit Commission's work—one of the most significant, important and far-reaching documents that any government could produce, let alone a new government; a document that will have enormous and far-reaching impacts on the people of Australia; a document which today highlights the failure of these people sitting opposite us—and what do we have brought into the parliament as the key issue of the day? One day after the release of the most important, most critical issue confronting the people of Australia today, the key issue being brought before us in the parliament is none other than this flimsy, false and unsubstantiated argument about the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer).

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody can say that the opposition, and in particular the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), has the least idea about tactics when in opposition because, if they did, they would have been running on a totally different issue today. The fact that they have run on this issue today just highlights how inadequate they are as an opposition which causes us to reflect on how inadequate they were as a government.

For an example of their inadequacy, one only has to point to the very person whom the opposition has chosen to lead the charge on this issue of integrity, ministerial propriety and honesty. The very person they have brought forward to lead the charge on this issue is none other than the member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton). We on this side of the House all know that the member for Kingsford‐Smith is a person who brings a reputation into this parliament which has some relevance to the issues of honesty, integrity and ministerial propriety. We all know about that because we have been following the course of politics in New South Wales for the last 25 or 30 years.

Members only have to cast their minds back to the preselection of the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating, the former member for Blaxland. Who featured in that preselection? It was not necessarily Paul Keating; it was one Laurie Brereton. Why? Because it was Laurie Brereton who was seen disappearing from the preselection meeting with a ballot box on the back of his motorbike. That was the first time we ever heard about Laurie Brereton, who later came into this political arena as the member for Kingsford‐Smith. That is a very healthy insight for those of us who sit here today hearing about honesty, integrity and ministerial propriety.

BREAK.PARA: This is the man whom the Labor opposition today brings forward to carry the flag of virtue on behalf of the Labor Party in this parliament. What a joke! If you follow today's carrier of the flag of virtue for the Labor Party through the course of his time as a senior member of the New South Wales Labor government, a senior minister in some incredibly sensitive and important portfolios, then you will appreciate the value of the joke that this Labor opposition is imposing on us here today. Cast your minds back to some critical issues that occurred during the period when the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith was in the New South Wales parliament. It just runs off the top of your head, does it not? You do not have to think hard. You can think of things like the Botany council, for goodness sake; this is an example of how they stand for virtue, integrity and honour.

One only has to go to things like the issues surrounding the monorail. Do honourable members remember the monorail? Oh dear, the monorail! On television last year we saw the former minister for public works and transport say that he had made a mistake. But throughout all the period that he was the minister championing the cause of the monorail, did he tell us the truth? Of course he did not and he admitted it many years later.

The reason why the background of the person who is bringing this charge against the Minister for Foreign Affairs is important to us today is that it gives us an insight into the way that these people opposite in the Labor Party value honesty, integrity, virtue and ministerial responsibility. The charge that they lay against the Minister for Foreign Affairs—a person who does have honesty and integrity—is very weak indeed because of the nature of the person they send forward to lead their charge.

One only has to go back to the period when he was in office here in the parliament in Canberra and to some of the things he did while he was in government as the Minister for Transport and Industrial Relations. Did he tell us the truth about AN? Did he tell us that there was an impending loss of $106 million in AN's forthcoming budget? Of course he did not. Did he hide the truth from us? Of course he did. Is he standing here today pretending that he has the virtues of truth and honesty? Of course he is. But do we believe it? No, of course we do not.

This is the man who did more to harm small business in Australia, by introducing the unfair dismissals provision, than anybody else on that side of the House when they were in government. This is the man who leads their charge today. Is this the person who told us the truth about the third runway? Did he tell us that only 13 per cent of all the takeoffs would be to the north of Sydney's Mascot airport? Did he tell us that? What was the truth of it? Twenty‐nine per cent of all of the takeoffs occurred to the north of Sydney's Mascot airport.

This is the man who was given the very sensitive responsibility of negotiating the single aviation market across the Tasman between Australia and New Zealand, a very important initiative announced by the former Prime Minister himself, one Paul J. Keating, just after the budget in 1993. He announced it and it was negotiated. The member for Kingsford‐Smith was the Minister for Transport at the time. What happened after that delicately negotiated single aviation market had been agreed on? People had shaken hands on it. Australia put its credibility on the line, shook hands with New Zealand and said, `This is a deal we will deliver on.' What happened? Two or three days before it was due to be implemented on 1 November 1994 it was scrapped by the minister at the time, the member for Kingsford‐Smith.

The circumstances of its scrapping tell a story about how these people appreciate honesty and ministerial responsibility. There is a story that goes with it: the then Secretary to the Department of Transport, Graham Evans—he is no longer there—had dinner with the current New Zealand High Commissioner, Mr Graham Fortune. They had dinner the night before it was revealed publicly that the single aviation market would be scrapped. Did they discuss it? Did Graham Evans, the then Secretary to the Department of Transport, raise such an important issue with the New Zealand High Commissioner? No, of course he did not. He did not raise it. Why? Because, as Graham Evans said later, `The minister, Laurie Brereton, told me not to.' In other words, tell the New Zealand High Commissioner anything else but the truth. This is the name of the game on the Labor side of the House and this is the very person they bring before us today to lay a charge in relation to honesty, integrity and ministerial responsibility.

Is this a sham or is it not? Of course it's a sham—a complete and utter sham. And the fact that they don't even believe it is proved by the fact that they brought the member for Kingsford‐Smith here today to lay that charge against the Minister for Foreign Affairs. If anything could be more `shamful', this is it. They should be ashamed of the fact that this person has brought this charge against the Minister for Foreign Affairs in this House today.

The Labor Party has imposed on the people of Australia a shadow minister for foreign affairs who has this track record. As a result of the track record of this person, Australia has had to mend its fences with New Zealand. It is a very interesting thing to look at the way the current Minister for Foreign Affairs has re-established our relationship with New Zealand. When the new government came into office it was made quite plain to us that the performance of the former Labor government and level of dishonesty engaged in by it had completely and utterly ruined the previously close relationship Australia and New Zealand had enjoyed for so many years. The new Minister for Foreign Affairs, Alexander Downer, has re-established the close relationship between Australia and New Zealand.

We were told by the former government, the Labor Party that sits in opposition here today, that if the Australian people voted for a coalition government the Asians would not deal with them, would not talk to them, would not have anything to do with them. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in view of the (a) increase in unemployment resulting from downsizing in both business and the public sector, (b) damage to effective enterprise functioning from downsizing due to the decline of employee morale, greater insecurity and loss of initiative and dynamism and (c) the repudiation of downsizing by business opinion leaders in the USA, calls on both business and public sector organisations to reject the perverse and destructive strategy of downsizing and contribute instead to employment generating economic and social development.

During the last decade downsizing has become the norm in large business and public sector organisations. Headlines such as `More jobs will go at Qantas, says chief', `Nissan to vote on redundancy', `ANZ to shed 2,500 staff in cost cutting drive', `Another 6,000 rail jobs will go' and `Commonwealth Bank to cut 7,500 workers' have become commonplace.

Labour shedding has become the fashion in big business. Some companies even reward their chief executives in proportion to the number of employees they get rid of. The enormity of CEO pay packages is sometimes now directly tied to the size of the cuts in the corporate work force. Such tactics are also reported in the more reactionary state governments, such as that under Premier Kennett in Victoria. The same tactics are being applied to public sector departments as to public sector business enterprises and to larger private businesses.

Most governments in Australia are aiming to minimise the number of people they employ. Minimising the size of organisational labour forces has virtually become an end in itself. Downsizing has become a powerful factor in the rise and persistence of high unemployment. Yet at exactly the time when unemployment is our principal problem, the principal, fashionable management trend has been to reduce staff. How ironic and perverse!

Future generations will be astonished at the magnitude and destructiveness of this contradiction. The theory behind downsizing has been simplistic. The argument has been that reducing the amount of labour input would improve productivity—that is, the same level of output could be produced with a decreasing number of inputs. At the very least, that is damaging to the economy. Robert Kuttner describes the paradox well when he says:

BREAK.PARA: . . . when one company becomes more competitive by doing more with less, the result is greater productivity. But when the entire economy competes that way, the income lost to displace workers may outweigh the gains to productivity. Unless we devise complementary strategies to yield jobs for the displaced, the `competitiveness' craze is likely to worsen this problem.

That was written several years ago before downsizing became such a widespread phenomenon. The argument of the downsizers was that increasing individual company productivity would restore high national economic growth rates. Kuttner demonstrates that this confuses two measures of productivity—that of the corporation with the productivity of the nation. Even if labour shedding led to improvements in corporate productivity, this may lead to such growth of waste nationally, through the loss of the output of unemployed workers and underemployed enterprises, that in other areas national productivity may in total decline.

However, as the experience with downsizing has grown, there has been a striking development. Managers themselves are starting to realise the destructive consequences for their own organisations of repeated reductions in the number of staff. The New York Times did a recent series of articles on the issue, which are full of quotations and stories relating to organisations in which downsizing has occurred. For example, in discussing consequences of the amalgamation of Chase Manhattan Bank with the Chemical Banking Corporation, and the consequent cut of 12,000 people, the articles report:

A huge insecurity complex has taken root in the Bank's employees. The deracinated workers feel forlorn, if not outright hostile. They are baffled about where their loyalties should lie—and where their employers' loyalty lies. Anxiety stalks the corridors.
There is intense trauma to those who lose their jobs as well as damage to the survivors. The insidious effect on one continuing employee is quoted as follows:

The merger has eliminated for me a certain motivation and all risk taking. We've all become soldiers, we will obey whatever is said and will not challenge. Since the merger it's a nine to five job for me.

So the mood has changed. Employees are more suspicious of management and less willing to participate in corporate activities. Some employees report great difficulty in maintaining motivation, and with that growth of lassitude productivity drops because employees feel despair rather than hope. There is widespread anger about the dimensions and frequency of lay‐offs. The instability generates pervasive paranoia.

A central problem is that in many corporations there have been repeated downsizings. A one-off exercise is damaging, but the consequences are clear when the exercise is repeated several times that everyone then feels insecure and any basis for renewing motivation and improving security is removed. Amongst those who remain, trust between colleagues is reduced and even disappears as they struggle to shore up their position. Many now believe that they cannot depend on their job any more. The effect has been pervasive economic anxiety.

In Australia, surveys conducted through the ANU found in 1989-90 that 27 per cent of respondents in employment felt various degrees of insecurity about their jobs, and that is high enough, but five years later, in 1994, a similar survey found that the proportion had risen to 43 per cent. That is, in addition to all of those who cannot find paid employment but want it, nearly half of those in employment feel a degree of insecurity about their tenure. No wonder anxiety and insecurity are the hallmarks of our age.

Belatedly, this destructive fad is being questioned. Some management experts argue that many companies downsize in a violent, overly hasty reaction to bad news. They cut without overhauling their strategy or the way they work. A recent survey by the American Management Association of 1,000 companies found that fewer than half the companies laying off people managed to increase their operating profits after workers were shed. The question that too many companies ask is: how can we get by with the minimum number of people? The director of management studies of the association states:
You're not going to grow if you simply do the same work with fewer people. You end up with a demoralised work force and no new business.

Other studies have come to similar conclusions. A survey conducted within the Harvard Business School recently studied lay‐offs over more than a decade in 100 large American companies. The survey found that often too many people are fired or the wrong ones retrenched and those who survive are not retrained to pick up the workload in the shrunken company. The researcher said:

Downsizing is typically viewed as a financial exercise. Companies add up their costs per employee and say if we sack 10,000 employees, that will save us that much in expenses and make us that much more profitable. So they cut 10,000 people across the board.
Yet that approach rarely succeeds. The Harvard Business School reports:
On average downsizing doesn't pay.

Indeed, lay‐offs have failed to pay off in many companies. The deep cuts can cripple product development, marketing and customer services as business evaporates. Management is forced into further cuts, sometimes with angry customers clamouring until management recognises its mistakes and starts to hire again.

All of this has led to one of the gurus of downsizing to recant. Stephen S. Roach, the Chief Economist at Morgan Stanley Bank, wrote to clients admitting that the downsizing approach is fundamentally flawed. He wrote:

For many years I have extolled the virtues of America's productivity led recovery. While I think it's safe to say that such a scenario has become the new mantra for US businesses in the 1990s, I must confess that I'm now having second thoughts . . . these doubts have caused me to rethink many of the glorious consequences I have long argued would be forthcoming in a truly productivity-led recovery. . . Slash and burn restructuring was not a permanent solution. Tactics of open-ended downsizing and real wage compression are ultimately recipes for industrial extinction.

If all you do is cut, you will eventually be left with nothing, with no market share. A myth has been there and I'm guilty of having perpetrated the myth—of the virtue of boosting companies by remaking the corporate entity into a more leaner, more flexible and competitive organisation. It's been a powerful learning experience for me because it takes me to the core of what I have been schooled in. At the end of the day, you can create wealth only if you've got a corporate sector that has its act together and takes a long-term strategic view. Do we get there by growing or—which is what we've been doing—by hollowing out companies.

I could continue. The important point I want to make in this debate is that downsizing has now been rejected as a strategy by many business leaders in the US. It is therefore vital that it also be rejected as a strategy by the public sector and the private sector in Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) has got his 10 minutes. By way of introduction, I have a great deal of respect for the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). He and I have disagreed on a number of things. I think his speech was a passionate plea for not downsizing. History has perhaps overtaken some of the comments that he has made. My understanding is that the US went through this process some time ago. Indeed, they are now in the phase of restructuring their existing companies to fully meet the needs that they perceive over the next decade.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a bit disappointed that the member for Fraser has just translated so-called downsizing into the Australian experience. At the end of the day, it is essential to look at what has happened in this country and, indeed, under the 13 years of his own government. I might be terribly wrong—if I do the member for Fraser an injustice, he has only to nod his head and I will immediately withdraw my comment—but I do not remember him standing up in this House when his own government was going through dramatic reductions in Commonwealth Public Service levels and pleading the case for his government to stop. If he did, I apologise. But I suspect that I am right.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not right, as my colleagues know well.
—If that is the situation, as I undertook, I apologise to you. But I make absolutely no apologies to the others on that side of the House who did not do similarly.
—You have got one more.

—I have given enough away today. They should hang their heads in shame, especially if they come into this House and talk about Public Service and private industry reduction. Just out of interest, between 1985 and 1995 the numbers in the Commonwealth Public Service fell by nearly 35,000, or 19 per cent, under the former Labor government.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Fraser talked about reductions in some states and singled out Victoria. I would have thought, given the reasonable man that he is, that he would have at least acknowledged that the Victorian government was left with a state, after the Cain‐Kirner years, that was financially moribund. They had absolutely no choice: they had to make extremely difficult and unpalatable decisions in relation to their own level of employment.

With the greatest respect to the member for Fraser, the greatest problem that he and his colleagues have is that they still fail to understand that, fundamentally, especially in the small business sector of this country, the great bulk of employers feel that their employees are their greatest asset. There is never any acknowledgment of that whatsoever. If the member for Fraser were to bother to go to the small businesses of his own electorate and ask them what their greatest asset is, I can tell you now that they would say that it is their employees.

During the Keating‐induced recession, the recession `we had to have', a large number of small business people went through equal trauma to that of their own employees whom they had to dismiss. They dismissed them not because they wanted to, not because they had read some book about downsizing in the Canberra or Melbourne libraries, or wherever it might be, not because of some philosophical bent about getting staff numbers down because of some paranoid desire to get rid of staff. It was a matter of utter necessity. If you ask anyone, in small business especially, what single task they hate most, they will tell you that it is laying off staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think congratulations are due to the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) on bringing this timely debate to the attention of the House. He objected to the Stalinist term `elimination of undesirable elements' and to the British usage of `pacification' in relation to India. If a bureaucrat, a clerk grade 5, was trying to accomplish a task he was given, a clerk grade 4 probably found a good reason why he should not do it. So the wheels went around and around within a wheel. We wound up with 40,000 or 50,000 public servants on the public payroll who were really not required and who not only were not contributing to the efficiency of supplying services to the public but were a detriment to good service provision.

So over time the government did relieve itself of that burden, which was paid for by the taxpayers. It is public funds. Remember, it is our taxes—yours, mine, the people sitting up in the gallery and all the people listening at home. It is our money, our taxes, that pay for public servants to do the job which we want done. If they are doing it inefficiently, then we need to change the mechanisms by which we supply the services.

In the private sector, I do not know of any company that would divest itself of personnel that it needed to produce its products; supply its services; do market research for it; help it sell or deliver its products in the marketplace; or do research and development to design new products or new vehicles of service which will gain it an increased market in the future. I do not know of any company that would deliberately divest itself of employees who could contribute to that good outcome which it sought.

I recognise that the member for Fraser is caught up a bit in his ideological warfare, that he has read a few articles that said that there were a few companies in the United States that overdid trying to become efficient as they found themselves more subject to international competition by virtue of the fact that their tariff walls and non-tariff trade barriers were falling as a result of GATT and as a result of more bilateral and multilateral agreements that the United States had signed. Maybe a few of them did go too far, and they are now in the process of hiring back. Maybe there are some companies in Australia that went too far, and they are now hiring back. If they are able to do that and maintain profits and their efficiency and productivity and, in fact, improve and increase their output, then I say `good on them', and I welcome that. I agree with the honourable member for Charlton that every person in this world should have productive work to do for the benefit of themselves and society.

The coalition's position was clear and unequivocal as far as the perception it keenly fostered for itself among small business was concerned: it would be changing the uplift factor, and this change would be a permanent one. Now we have this legislation which alters the uplift factor for one year only—the 1996-97 financial year—but which makes no mention of changes subsequent to that year, nor does it reset the default rate at a lower figure than is presently the case.

The coalition may make great exhortations about default rates, but the legislation before the House this evening makes no attempt to reset the default rate at a figure other than is presently the case. I note that the member for Braddon (Mr Miles) is leaving the chamber. He was interjecting quite vociferously and vocally on the whole notion of default rates being at lower figures than is presently the case.

The government's attempts to fudge its position and back away from its promise are obvious from the words of the member for Braddon. He said in his second reading speech that the bill will give effect to the coalition's promise and election commitment to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor for the next financial year to six per cent. As the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) has so succinctly said, there is no mention of anything beyond that. In fact, one could only assume, as did many small business owners and many self-funded retirees in Isaacs, that this would be a policy initiative on which voters based their election choice—that this would be legislated in perpetuity. We have already heard the forecast CPI figures out to the year 1999-2000. It is for half the projected uplift factor that may well be contained in the silent aspects of this legislation, being some 10 per cent.

This is a shonky and deceitful attempt to hoodwink the Australian voters in a way that we on this side of the House have come to expect. Those of us who have been in this chamber for a lot longer than me know what happened in 1977. This is no better than the deceit which was perpetrated on the Australian people in that instance. In fact, this matter is of similar duplicity. (Time expired)
