DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 20 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

A bill with substantially the same content to this was introduced to the parliament by the previous government in November 1995. However, the bill lapsed due to the prorogation of parliament this year. Today's bill differs in only two respects from the one introduced by the previous government: (i) the title has been altered and (ii) subitem 4(1), schedule 8 has been deleted because the 30 April 1996 deadline for that particular provision has passed.

The previous government's bill introduced a number of measures which would result in significant savings over the next three years. These savings have already been incorporated in the forward estimates. For this reason, the government is introducing this bill which incorporates these savings measures.

However, I would like to make it very clear that this step does not provide any indication about what may or may not be the subject of ongoing budget discussions. The results of these discussions will be made public at a later time—in fact, on 20 August, which is entirely appropriate; it is when the budget will be announced to the parliament and the nation—and will not be influenced by our decision to introduce this bill now.

BREAK.PARA: This bill reduces the maximum annual grant from $250,000 to $200,000, providing for fairer distribution of the available funding amongst small and medium exporters. This bill introduces the framework for a flexible grants entry test. This will both limit the payment of grants to claimants who are least likely to succeed and increase the guidance provided to Australia's smaller exporters.

The accountability and risk management aspects of the export market development grants scheme will be improved by the other measures contained in the bill. The amount by which a claim for grant can be increased between the time of lodgement and its assessment will be limited. This will reduce the scope for lodgement of ill‐prepared or ambit claims.

A limit will be placed on the number of EMDG approved joint venture and consortiums of which a `person' may be a member. This will reduce the potential for individual organisations to receive very large amounts of EMDG funding through multiple membership.

Austrade will be given the power to reduce the grant paid to an AJVC claimant to the extent that the claimant has breached the conditions of approval of its AJVC status. Grants will not be paid where a consultant convicted of fraud or dishonesty offences has prepared the claim or where the expenditure in the claim is related to illegal activities.

Finally, the act will be amended so that the general prohibition on the payment of grants in relation to `in house' expenses cannot be circumvented through the use of interposed companies. I commend this bill to honourable members in this the last sitting week planned for the autumn session.

I would add that it is the wish of the government that this bill be passed in accordance with the undertakings that were given by the previous government, so that those who are submitting applications in respect of this financial year, finishing on 30 June, in a few days time, will do so on the basis of having a firm framework with regard to their applications and the processing of those applications. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a short speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a very short speech. It is the things that were not said that are most relevant in this context. It is not just the speech of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer), that is relevant; it is what is not in this bill rather than what is actually in it.
—It is your bill.

—For that reason, the opposition does not oppose the bill. As the Deputy Prime Minister has alluded to in his own speech, other than stylistic changes and a certain commencement date the bill mirrors the previous government's Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995, which was sponsored by the then trade minister, the then Senator Bob McMullan. That bill lapsed with the dissolution of the parliament. I thank the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade for his courtesy in alerting me to his introduction of this bill at an earlier than usual stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill amends the Export Market Development Grants Act to reduce the maximum grant payable in any one year from $250,000 to $200,000 and introduces a range of improved administrative accountability and risk management measures. The legislation also introduces registration and grant entry testing of first‐time claimants.

The second reading speech of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) together with evidence given to the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee on export readiness and administrative burdens, are matters which are worth drawing attention to. I propose to do that in the course of my contribution.

PARA.BREAK: As I have said, the context of this bill is much more important than the bill itself and it is what is not here rather than what is. That context of course is the continuity of the export market development grants scheme. The current indications are that the government is considering either abolishing or substantially amending or cutting the EMDG scheme in breach of numerous express elec tion commitments. The bill must be examined in that light, namely, whether this government does have a commitment to increasing exports, to keeping jobs and to keeping election commitments.

SPEECH.PARA: The attitude of the opposition on this bill is that it is about keeping the government honest and up to the mark as far as its election commitments are concerned. The concerns of the opposition are reflected in an amendment to the motion for the second reading which I will formally move at the conclusion of my remarks. I outline that amendment. It says:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"while not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) is of the opinion that the export market development grants Scheme is:

PARA.TAB: (a) a successful scheme which enhances Australia's export performance,
(b) a source of job creation and benefits Australia's balance of payments, and
(c) a successful export incentive for small and medium sized enterprises;

SPEECH.PARA: (2) expresses grave concern at the Government's mooted abolition of the scheme which would be:

PARA.TAB: (a) a cynical and blatant breach of an express election commitment to retain and expand the scheme, and

(b) counter to any reasonable assessment of the evidence given to the Senate Legislative Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in the course of the Committee's consideration of the Bill; and

SPEECH.PARA: (3) condemns the Government for its failure to meet its election commitment to extend the Scheme by making full Export Market Development grants of 50% available to the tourism industry".

My colleague the member for Cunningham and shadow minister for sport and tourism (Mr Martin) will formally move an amendment in the consideration in detail stage to reflect that election commitment on the part of the government so far as the tourism industry is concerned.

The EMDG scheme, which is administered by Austrade, was instituted by the Whitlam Labor government in 1974 to encourage Australian businesses to seek out new export markets for Australian goods and services. It is worth while referring to a short extract from the second reading speech on its introduction by the then Minister for Overseas Trade, who said:

. . . the emphasis in a new export incentive scheme should be on market development rather than perpetuating payments on exports. Under the previous export incentive arrangements the bulk of the benefits went to a few large companies. Moreover, because the benefits under the schemes took the form of rebates of income tax and payroll tax liability, many small exporting firms and other bodies engaged in export such as statutory marketing authorities and co‐operatives were disadvantaged.

The scheme should not involve rebates of tax and benefits should be in the form of grants; particular encouragement should be given to small and medium sized firms to become involved in exporting; there should be a ceiling limit on the benefits received by any one firm or group of firms; and there should be a better balance established between the costs of revenue and benefits to the exporting sector.
The limit proposed in the 1974 legislation which instituted the scheme was a maximum of $100,000. In this bill the maximum amount is reduced from $250,000 to $200,000.

The scheme itself is generally regarded as a successful export incentive scheme. As I have indicated, it currently provides taxable cash grants of up to $250,000 per annum, based on the expenditure incurred by an Australian person or company seeking to create or expand exports of their products in overseas markets. Provided that the person has incurred at least $30,000 of eligible expenditure in one year, they will be entitled to a grant.

The grant is calculated at 50 per cent of eligible expenditure after the first $15,000. Claimants can receive up to eight grants that are subject to a performance test after two grants. Eligible expenditure includes upfront marketing costs, such as travel expenses, special promotional literature, and overseas representations. Companies which record export sales above $25 million per annum are ineligible to apply for a grant.

The success of this scheme is evidenced by the fact that over 69,000 grants were made between 1974 and 1991. The history and the experience of this scheme are that most grants are in the range of $65,000. In 1994‐95 approximately 3,400 exporters received a total of over $210 million. Projections made in 1995 expect the scheme to grow to around $290 million by 1998-99. The average grant in the order of $65,000 is one of the reasons why the opposition does not object to the reduction of the maximum grant from $250,000 to $200,000.

Experience has been that some 70 per cent of all the recipients are small and medium exporters with 25 or fewer employees. That bears out the ambition and aspiration of the then minister for overseas trade when the original legislation was introduced. In 1994, as part of the Working Nation statement, the previous federal government announced the extension of the EMDG scheme for a further five years to 1999, and projections were that, as a consequence, assistance would be afforded to up to 5,000 exporters per year.

All this detailed information points to a very effective and valuable scheme that continues to significantly assist Australian exporters seeking out new markets for Australian goods. New markets for Australian goods and services mean more jobs for Australians. More jobs mean better living standards and a stronger economy.

So the key benefits of this scheme are that it acts as an incentive for Australian companies to consider and seek out export markets. Increased export activity means increased job opportunities. The scheme returns a high percentage to the Commonwealth through tax receipts, and reviews of this scheme have indicated that that can be in the order of 42 per cent of returns through tax receipts. The scheme has a high multiplier effect—some estimates are as high as 30 to one—with usual estimates in the range of $9 to $10 for every dollar granted. The scheme is widely regarded as having helped foster an export culture amongst small and medium sized companies.

PARA.BREAK: The benefit of the scheme was seen in submissions and in evidence given to the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee. This bill was intro duced into the Senate and the Senate, in its wisdom, referred the bill to the Senate legislation committee to consider the content of the bill and also to consider the bill in the context of the continuity of the scheme. A range of parties gave evidence to the Senate committee. I think it is worth while relaying to the House some of the evidence from interested parties. The Australian Publishers Association, through its immediate past president, Ms Susan Donavan, said as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The good news is that, almost as a direct result of the scheme, our industry has seen exports increase by 100% over a four year period. In the period 1990‐1994, our exports grew from $41 million to over $80 million and we have tabled those figures.
The Australian Institute of Exporters, through Mr Russell Chandler, said in evidence:

The scheme is cheap to administer, with some 95% of its budget going directly to the exporter, and independent research has shown that for each $1 paid in rebate additional export marketing expenditure of $2.60 results and additional exports of between $15 and $25 result. . . . on an after‐tax basis, it is estimated that the government directly claws back 42% of the scheme's cost and indirectly claws back unidentified additional revenue relating to sales tax, payroll tax et cetera. In summary, of the $196 million paid in rebate in respect of the 1993-94 financial year, the maximum real cost was $114 million.
Further:
. . . the EMDG scheme is focused, efficient and a relevant scheme offering measurable financial benefits to Australia in the short and long term.
Those are just two examples of many pieces of evidence which go to the success of this particular scheme.

The testament to the scheme's success does not just lie in the evidence of these industry groups to the Senate committee. The scheme has been the subject of a number of reviews, and all those within recent years. All those reviews have concluded that the scheme is successful and achieves what it sets out to do, namely, to encourage Australian business to seek out export markets.

There are two key reviews which are referred to so far as the analysis of the EMDG scheme is concerned. In 1994, a review of the scheme involving the Departments of Finance and Treasury was undertaken by Austrade in consultation with Price Waterhouse and Professor Brewley of the University of New South Wales. That review was entitled Helping to meet the export challenge, and the review found that the scheme was achieving its object of encouraging Australian companies to seek out and develop new export markets. The key findings of that review were as follows:
The EMDG Scheme is achieving its objective of assisting Australian businesses—especially small and medium sized firms—to seek out and develop new export markets.
Revenues from taxes on grants receipts and profits on additional exports were estimated to return 42% of the cost of the scheme to the Commonwealth.

Most of the growth in the EMDG scheme has come from the services sector, accounting for 45 per cent of all grants at the time of the review, with manufacturers at 37%, traders at 15% and primary producers at 3%.
The minimum level of qualifying expenditure, the grant rate, number of grants and performance test are largely appropriate.
EMDG recipients are highly committed to exporting in terms of exporting and investment. On average exporting activity accounts for 50% of the employment and investment of EMDG recipients.
EMDG recipients increased their own spending on export market promotion by more than the value of the grant.

The second review of this scheme, which is frequently referred to, is an Auditor‐General's efficiency audit on the scheme in 1993‐94—ANOA Audit Report No. 33 —and Austrade has effectively implemented all the recommendations which were made by the audit office.

That, I think, is a reasonably accurate analysis of the history of the scheme and its success to date and, as a consequence of that knowledge, it was not surprising in the course of the recent election campaign to see the coalition committing itself to a continuation of the scheme. In the coalition's Meeting the challenges: Liberal and National Party trade strategies for the future, the coalition expressly committed itself in the following terms:

Australia's Export Market Development Grants (EMDG) Scheme has been in operation since 1975, and has been supported by Australia's export businesses. The coalition will retain the Scheme but will undertake its review to ensure that it remains as a source of assistance to small and medium businesses and look at ways that access to grants can be made more efficient.
That was on page 3 of the relevant policy document. At page 30 of the same document, under the title `Export incentives', is the bald phrase:
We will maintain the Export Market Development Grants (EMDG) Scheme.

Those particular commitments were added to by the then shadow minister for trade and now Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) on 15 February 1996 in the course of a debate with the then Minster for Trade, Mr McMullan, who had by then resigned as a senator to stand as a candidate for the seat of Canberra. In the course of that policy debate at the National Press Club, the now Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade said:
. . . also it is a privilege to present the Coalition trade policy, `Meeting the Challenges' and debate that policy.
He went on to say:
And finally, ladies and gentlemen, we of course have as the fifth track in relation to our approach to trade, the promoting and financing of Australian exports.
Austrade stays, the EMDG scheme stays . . .
That was a bald commitment to the continuation of the program.

It comes as no surprise that consistent speculation that the scheme will either be abolished or have its funding and scope substantially reduced has seen a range of continued expressions of concern from relevant industry sectors about the continuation of this scheme and the danger that the coalition government will not meet its expressed election commitments. As far as industry sectors are concerned, what has been alarming so far has been the deafening silence on the part of relevant ministers to give any sense of continued commitment to those particular commitments I have referred to.

In this House, in the course of any number of question times, the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) has refused to commit and reaffirm himself to those commitments. The Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) has likewise refused to commit himself to those commitments. The Minister for Trade, the Deputy Prime Minister, has been deafening by his silence and his refusal to indicate whether the commitments he gave as shadow minister for trade and the commitment he gave at the National Press Club stand.

As early as April we saw the threat to this particular program. In the Financial Review of 19 April, an article by Tom Burton and Louise Dodson entitled `Razor gang takes aim: export scheme faces abolition under Budget plan' reported:
The Federal Government is turning its guns on exporters, with a plan to abolish the $237 million Export Market Development Grants scheme being considered as part of the attack on government spending.
The move to abolish the scheme, which is the major assistance program for exporters, would have a major impact on small business—a key constituency the Coalition appealed to in the recent election.
The abolition of the EMDG scheme would represent a major breach of the Coalition's promise to maintain the scheme.
On page 2 of the same report, in an analysis by David Shires, Mr Shires reminded us that the government has form in this particular matter when he said:
Prime Minister Mr John Howard tried to remove it once before: in the 1987 election campaign.
The then president of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, Mr Peter Frankel, resigned from the Liberal Party very publicly.

As we are growing accustomed to with the government, it is one thing in the run‐up to the election but it is another thing when you now see its natural instincts. The managing director of the Australian Business Chamber, Mr Philip Holt, was reported in the Daily Telegraph Mirror on 20 May this year, and I refer to his reported comments. The article reads:

Australian Business Chamber managing director Philip Holt said any attempt to abolish the $237 million export market development grants would be a major backward step for small and medium‐sized businesses.
Mr Holt said if reports of the abolition were correct, the Government would be breaking an election promise and affect job creation and increase the balance of payments deficit.
"This scheme helps small and medium businesses get into export markets, markets politicians have been telling us for years are vital to the Australian economy,"
There is an election commitment the coalition made which I have not yet referred to but now will. Page 9 of the coalition trade document states:

When all is said and done, the foundations for a successful trade strategy are the export activities of companies and individuals. Accordingly we will welcome the contribution of the business community through Chambers of Manufactures and Chambers of Commerce and Industry, and other similar bodies to improve our international trade performance.

I hope the Deputy Prime Minister takes note of that particular comment from Mr Holt and also the comments made in evidence to the Senate committee. Those sorts of contributions litter the relevant materials on this particular subject. In the Business Review Weekly of 10 June, an article headed `Will the razor gang slice export grants?' states:
A scheme that has helped thousands of companies and generated strong export income is threatened by Canberra cost‐cutting.

There are a couple of quotes in this particular article which I will draw the attention of the House to. Trevor Tappenden, responsible for Ernst and Young's national entrepreneurial services divisions, says:
EMDG has been a saviour to Australian small business getting into new export markets. It has created an environment for them to increase our exports.
Mr Holt, whom I have referred to, is also included in this article. Mr Holt says he `can't believe any government would be so stupid as to dump the EMDG'. He continues:

This country must export and keep increasing its exports, and that growth increasingly is coming from small business, who are the ones who mainly use and must have this support . . . and then this happens . . . it sure isn't what we thought would come from the small business policy that promised to make the climate better for the sector.

Mr Holt goes on to say that `the speculation is that business will fear the worst and be grateful that the scheme is only cut, not dismembered'. I will refer the House shortly to express commitments the Deputy Prime Minister gave in the course of 1995 that the scheme would not be substantially tinkered with.

In the course of the formal submissions given to the Senate committee to which I have referred, we find a number worth drawing attention to. The MTIA, Australia's manufacturing, engineering and construction industry association, said in its formal submission to the committee—and this submission is signed by Leigh Purnell, one of its directors:

I wanted to take the opportunity presented by the current reference to raise with you MTIA's enormous concerns regarding the mooted abolition of the Export Market Development Grants (EMDG) Scheme. MTIA met with the Prime Minister last month during which we explained our concerns on this matter in detail.

Industry is totally opposed to any move by the Government to break its election promise to retain the EMDG scheme. It is essential that Australian exporters are provided with both a strong domestic base from which to export and effective forms of export assistance.

Any reduction in funding for export assistance schemes would be short-sighted in the extreme, particularly given the level of Australia's current account deficit, and would have the inevitable result of reducing the export promotion activities which industry is able to undertake.
The Australian Institute of Export (NSW) Ltd, in the conclusion to its submission, said:

The fact is that the Coalition Government promised not only to maintain the Scheme in general, but also, to enhance it for the developing tourist industry. It can be presumed that it had good reasons to make this election promise other than to win votes. The promise coincided with the Labor Government policy which had seen the scheme extended to 1999.
It is clearly demonstrated by independent research that the Scheme repays the nation in employment and taxes via production and exports to a much greater extent than its cost.

The major thrust of the Scheme is towards small to medium entrepreneurs and exporters who have been the substantial contributors to recent large improvement in manufacturing and knowledge based exports.
Those sorts of comments litter the submissions made to the Senate committee.

BREAK.PARA: I have referred to the formal submissions, but some of the comments that were made in the course of the Senate committee's public hearing are worth drawing attention to. Mr Peter Campbell, the President of the Australian Publishers Association, gave evidence:
We had a meeting last year with the shadow trade minister (Tim Fischer), who gave us his personal and unequivocal commitment to the future of the grants scheme.
Susan Donavan, the past president, said in evidence:

Last year we studied with great interest the policy statements of both parties and took great comfort from the fact that both the coalition and the Labor Government promised to continue the scheme into the year 1999. As well as that, our industry group had a meeting with the then shadow minister Mr Fischer, who gave us his personal assurance that the scheme would continue to that date.
We received a letter from him last week which concluded by saying:
The process, as you say, has still not been resolved and will be an ongoing process. Consequently I am not able to comment on the future of the scheme.
This is from the man who told the National Press Club `EMDG stays'. Susan Donavan completed her evidence by saying:

As people committing large amounts of money to export, this fills us with terror, particularly at a time when all publishers are putting together their budgets for the next financial year and making very strong commitments, both in developing products that will not be able to proceed if the scheme is abolished.

Senator Cook, in the other place, put some questions on notice to the Australian Publishers Association because he was not able to get all his questions in in the allotted time. One of the questions which the Australian Publishers Association, Sue Donavan, took on notice was the following:
How does the Association view the widely reported rumours that the ERC has decided to abolish the EMDG Scheme?
The answer was provided as follows:

The Association is extremely concerned about the threat to the future of the Scheme, especially in view of the Government's election commitment to maintain it. This commitment was contained in the presentation of the Coalition's trade policy by Hon. Tim Fischer MP, as Shadow Minister for Trade to the National Press Club on 15 February 1996, and repeated on Pages 1 & 8 of the Coalition's Industry and Commerce Policy document released by Hon. John Moore MP (Shadow Minister for Industry, Commerce and Public Administration). These pronouncements reinforce the clear and unequivocal commitment to continue the Scheme, without fiddling amendments, until 1999. This was also given to me by Mr Fischer at a meeting in his office on 29 June 1995. At this meeting, Mr Fischer acknowledged the concerns put to him that frequent adjustments to EMDG confused exporters, complicated the claiming process and undermined the financial reliability of the Scheme as an aid in planning future promotional efforts.

I leave to one side the question of whether the introduction of this bill by the minister is in breach of that personal assurance. Certainly, what we find in the Australian of Monday, 17 June is in breach of that. An article in the Australian entitled `Funding cuts hit export scheme' reports:

Federal Cabinet's razor gang has retreated from a threat to abolish a $240 million trade promotion scheme in this year's Budget . . . In the first round of Budget planning, the Expenditure Review Committee has decided to cut funding to the Export Market Development Grants scheme—the leading program for assisting exporters—by about 50 per cent.

Senior government sources said the trade promotion agency, Austrade, had been asked to examine how the spending cap placed on the EMDG could be implemented and returned to the ERC with proposals when the second round of Budget meetings starts on July 2.

Given the evidence of the Australian Publishers Association, the government will not be able to slide out of this election commitment by slashing the scheme and then saying that it has continued the scheme by not abolishing it.

The Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee recommended in its majority report to the Senate that the bill be enacted in its current form. Senator Cook produced a minority report, and I will read the recommendations of Senator Cook's minority report. He recommended that the bill as introduced be amended in the following areas:
7.1 a transitional provision is included to phase in the reduction of the grant ceiling of $250,000 to $200,000, so that firms are not commercially disadvantaged; and,
7.2 the Government consults with industry to make more transparent the conditions under which a market test will apply, or abolish such a test.
7.3 the government consults with industry on the new accountability and risk management measures with a view to reducing the complexity and red tape involved.

In addition to those very grave concerns about the continuity of the scheme, much of the evidence that was given to the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee was in respect of the export ready test and the administrative burden that, according to industry, measures in this bill will impose.

Senator Brownhill, representing the Minister for Trade in the Senate, gave a number of undertakings in the course of debate about technical and other matters which other senators placed him on notice they would certainly monitor. Without going through the detail of those, that is the attitude of the opposition in this House as well.

This bill is important for what is not contained in it as much as for what is there. The opposition does not oppose the bill. We do oppose the government's continuing deafening silence in respect of the continuation of the scheme. Whilst the Minister for Trade may well be silent at this stage, we will be doing our best to ensure that if we discover, as we expect, in the course of the budget on 20 August that the scheme is abolished or gutted, then we will be drawing attention to the personal assurances that have been given.
I have indicated in the course of my remarks that I have circulated an amendment to the motion for the second reading. I now take the opportunity of formally moving that. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"while not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) is of the opinion that the export market development grants Scheme is:

PARA.TAB: (a) a successful scheme which enhances Australia's export performance,
(b) a source of job creation and benefits Australia's balance of payments, and
(c) a successful export incentive for small and medium sized enterprises;

BREAK.PARA: (2) expresses grave concern at the Government's mooted abolition of the scheme which would be:

PARA.TAB: (a) a cynical and blatant breach of an express election commitment to retains and expand the scheme, and

(b) counter to any reasonable assessment of the evidence given to the Senate Legislative Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in the course of the Committee's consideration of the Bill; and

BREAK.PARA: (3) condemns the Government for its failure to meet its election commitment to extend the Scheme by making full Export Market Development grants of 50% available to the tourism industry'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise tonight to speak on the government's Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. I found that at the end of his remarks the shadow minister, the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), was somewhat confused. He spoke of concerns that the opposition has about some of the detailed points of this bill and whether they will disadvantage or hurt industry. The reason I had some difficulty with that is that this bill was essentially produced by the former ALP government, those people who are now sitting in opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, the shadow minister was sitting on this side of the House last year when the government introduced almost the same bill. There are a couple of very minor changes. One is the name of the bill; the other is the elimination of a minor bit of the earlier bill which, because of the time that has elapsed since it was introduced, is no longer applicable.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the changes that this bill introduces to the export market development grants scheme are changes which will clean up the act and make it applicable to a greater number and a greater range of small and medium‐sized businesses. The act has undergone a great number of changes throughout its life since 1975. I have spoken in this House on no less than four occasions on changes to the export market development grants scheme and on changes that should have occurred to that scheme a long time ago but which we still have not caught up with.

This bill which, as I said, is a former ALP government bill, was introduced in the Senate in order to get these changes through because the parliament was running out of time. SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of major points to this bill about which I would like to speak briefly. Firstly, the bill will reduce the maximum annual grant from $250,000 to $200,000. That will spread the available funds around a bit more and allow a bit more participation by small and medium‐sized businesses. After all, the original purpose of the EMDGS was to encourage small and medium‐sized businesses to get into the business of export.

The former government had no overall, integrated plan about how industry should develop or how government should help it to develop or restructure. It had no plans for industry, just a hodgepodge of shotgun approaches. This scheme was one of them. The former government thought it might be a good idea if they gave industry some money to help itself. It thought that would do a bit to improve exports.

This scheme has helped; there is no question about that. It is one of a range of the former government's grants and development programs which has had a positive effect in encouraging Australian business to export. But its original purpose was to encourage small and medium‐sized businesses to export. That is why I have no problem with reducing the maximum annual grant from $250,000 to $200,000.

The other major point is that the bill introduces the framework for a flexible grants entry test. Presently, the rules are so rigid that many small and medium‐sized businesses have difficulty understanding let alone meeting the criteria without hiring consultants to help them apply. This new mechanism will allow Austrade some flexibility. For those companies which clearly have a future, which have a good show of achieving their objectives—which have products and services for export, not just this year but next year—Austrade has the opportunity to approve their applications without overly burdening them with bureaucratic procedure, such as forms, filing and all the rest of it.

I believe it was last year or the year before that I noted in a speech on the export market development grants scheme that far too many companies applied for grants, got the grants, were successful in the first year and fell over in year two or three or four or five. They had one shot. They spent their $30,000. They got their grant and something happened, but obviously it did not do very much to improve Australian exports because they did not continue with it.

That is one of the complaints I have had about the scheme for a long time. We want to make sure this thing is targeted to those companies who really use it to benefit Australia. That is what it is all about, isn't it? It is not about handing out taxpayers' money to companies so they can get on a bit of a gravy train. The scheme is about encouraging those companies that otherwise might not market their products or services in another country, to help us with our balance of payments problem, to help us try to eliminate the current account deficit and to do something about the horrible deficit we have in our terms of international trade.

The grants scheme is about encouraging companies to develop marketing programs to take their products and services offshore. I think it is a fine objective. The amendments to this bill will help make it easier for some small businesses to be successful in applying to be registered under the scheme, whereas prior to these amendments they might not have been successful.

Another major point the bill addresses is the fact that the amount by which a grant can be increased between the time of lodgment and the time of assessment will be limited. I am advised that some companies make a regular practice of putting in an ambit claim, except not a high ambit claim like the unions but perhaps a low ambit claim. Then, through the course of the year, they decide to spend up big but not notify the department so, when it comes time to put in the paperwork for the grant, all of a sudden the department receives a very large request for funds when it had expected something more modest.

This amendment essentially says that you ought to know what it is you are going to do and that you ought to have a program in advance of making your first claim so you know exactly what you are going to do. The amendment will let you increase your claim by 10 per cent between time of lodgment and time of assessment by the department and you can decrease it, if necessary. That seems totally reasonable to me. I am aware of the fact that it is based on experience, rather than on some ideological concept.

Another of the major points the bill addresses is the number of approved joint ventures. The bill will limit the number of approvals. Some problems generated by joint ventures have been reported. Some companies have decided to make a regular practice out of joining joint ventures. One single company joins one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine—heaps of joint ventures. They all get a piece of the action and it sort of leapfrogs. They beat what was a $250,000 maximum grant and the now $200,000 maximum grant by adding claim on to claim on to claim. I suspect that at the same time some of these companies are also receiving other government grants and benefits for industry which involve research and development and perhaps some of the other programs.

Perhaps this is the appropriate time. The former government generally relied on five major programs to try to encourage industry to develop in Australia and to export. These five major programs were not integrated with an overall macro-economic policy that was designed to encourage Australian manufacturing and development of Australian industry, nor was it associated with micro-economic policy which sought to improve cost‐effectiveness to Australian industry by reducing the costs of transport, power and all the rest of the utilities to companies, by reducing the cost of government regulation. The former Labor government attacked each of these areas as an issue on its own. The program, to my mind, was never integrated. It was never designed to achieve an overall outcome, but each of the programs was set aside on its own.

One of these major programs is the one we are debating here tonight—the export market development grants scheme. Another is the government's 150 per cent taxation benefit for research and development programs. The third one is the computer bounty which we debated in this House last year and which the former government sought to change dramatically and which ultimately was brought back more closely to what the program originally contained because it was found that many companies which had moved to manufacture printed circuit boards in Australia would have been dramatically disadvantaged had that scheme just been cancelled without access to any other government benefit at the same time.

A fourth major government program has been the factor F pharmaceutical scheme, which has sought to encourage pharmaceutical companies to develop their research and development efforts and to produce drugs in Australia for both the Australian market and for export, and to do this by giving them grants which really offset some of the price differential between the low price that the Australian government sets for its pharmaceuticals through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the much higher average general price that those pharmaceuticals would attain in the international marketplace—in other words, the average wholesale selling price on the international market. That latter price is most generally very much higher than what the Australian government will pay pharmaceutical companies for their products.

This was a temporary, interim measure brought in by former Senator John Button when he was industry minister. It has had a huge impact on a number of pharmaceutical companies, including Glaxo, which is headquartered in my electorate and which has become a major producer of pharmaceuticals in the Australian context and exporter and is doing heaps of research and development. This program, together with the 150 per cent R&D, was a factor in helping to kick-start them, to get them going from a low base to up the ante. That has been true of a number of other pharmaceutical companies as well.

Today we have a pharmaceutical manufacturing industry. When I entered this parliament in 1990 I was concerned that our pharmaceutical industry was headed towards zero and we looked like importing just about the lot. That has been turned around, and that is good.

The former government had two other programs of which bits and pieces are continuing. One of those is the automotive plan and the other is the textile, clothing and footwear plan, which offers a number of incentives to companies if they take into account a number of factors and reduce their staff and try to hang on producing in Australia rather than giving up as tariffs came down rather rapidly over a reasonably short period.

Another major point of this bill is that Austrade will now have the power to reduce grants to a claimant where the condition of approval or its status have been breached. In other words, if the company has done the wrong thing, Austrade will have the power to reduce the grant in the areas where the company has done the wrong thing. I see no problem with that.

BREAK.PARA: Another point is that grants will not be paid when a consultant to a company preparing a claim for the company is found to have been convicted of fraud. This clause does not delete the company's entire claim; it would simply delete the portion that was affected by the individual who had been convicted of fraud. Without having any knowledge, I suspect that this amendment was brought into the act because of experience over time.

The last major item that I believe the bill addresses is that there is now a prohibition on payments of grants to prevent payments for in-house expenses, which have not always been allowable, but to prevent companies from circumventing the rules by the use of interposed companies. For instance, when calling an outside consultant `a consultant' in order to try to build up expense where it is simply transferring expense from general company overheads to an outside consultant, the amount of money transferred through that artificial accounting practice would be disallowable.

The export market development grants scheme has been a good scheme for industry. It has encouraged export. One of the things that the former government never did, which I was highly critical of for a long period, was that it treated the tourism industry differently from every other kind of industry. For some reason it had this ideological hang‐up that because there was a whole separate grants mechanism for the tourist industry, which financed generic advertising of Australia in overseas markets, because we spent that money, somehow the ALP had a hang‐up that we should not treat our tourism operators in this country the same as manufacturers or other service providers.

For a very long time—in fact, until last year—the government refused to consider tourism at all. It has been in and out of these kinds of schemes for a long time. They finally decided that, if you were an inbound tourism operator and you offered a whole range of services, you might satisfy the requirements of the act, but you would only get paid 50 per cent of what everybody else got, being 25 per cent of your eligible expenditure. I always thought that that was wrong. As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, which inquired into that aspect of the EMDG scheme, I strongly supported a finding that it was inequitable and we were treating some Australian businesses differently from other Australian businesses. I have always deplored that.

I have a great range of small tourism operators in my electorate who are very important. Business is important nationally. With over three million tourist visitors to the electorate of La Trobe every year, I speak with some power of influence in this area. I encourage the government to rectify this anomaly at the earliest possible moment. I recommend the bill to the House. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —A petition was tabled in the House today, not on its face a very remarkable petition—it was a small petition about gun control with 60 signatures. But it is a petition with a very fine story behind it, which I would like to draw to the attention of the House. The petition was organised by a grade 4 student at Holy Trinity School in Curtin, in my electorate. The student, Niamh Dobson, is nine years old.

BREAK.PARA: A letter from the school drew to my attention that this petition was coming. Niamh Dobson wrote to me asking me if I would present the petition. In her letter she said:

Will you please present this petition regarding gun control laws to Parliament as soon as possible. When our teacher explained about gun control laws after the terrible shooting in Tasmania I decided to have a petition in our school.
I was, of course, struck by that letter. Who could have received it and not been struck by it? It is a remarkable story.

I therefore got my office to get in contact with the class teacher. She told me that they had a class discussion during a religion lesson about how hard it is sometimes to deal with injustices in the community, and how an individual acting alone can find social change difficult but how working together people can make a difference.

This was a generalised discussion, not specifically related to the issue of gun control. But the teacher tells me that after the class Niamh asked how people working together could do something to achieve stronger gun laws. The teacher, being a responsible citizen, tried to put a series of options, saying that there are various things one can do. She mentioned the option of petitioning the parliament, how citizens can express their points of view collectively to the parliament through a petition.

Possibly to the teacher's very pleasant surprise, this was not the end of the matter. It was not then forgotten. Niamh decided that this was the method she would use. A delegation from the class approached the principal and obtained the principal's approval to persist with this idea, to develop it further and to petition the parliament.

The principal suggested, probably quite appropriately, that it might not be appropriate for all the children to sign, as some may not fully understand the implications of what they were signing. So they put an advertisement in the school newsletter and sought and received the support of many of the parents. Therefore, we have the petition which was tabled today, a petition from citizens in my electorate and in the ACT generally, with 60 signatures.

The teacher advised me that young Niamh Dobson saw this project through from beginning to end virtually on her own: from the original discussion which sparked her thought, to the delegation to the principal, to the advertisement in the school newsletter, to the collection of the signatures and to the letter to me, which led ultimately to its presentation.

The teacher also said to my staff that we should keep this young student's name in mind—with that record of organisation, we might see her in this place one day. Given that she is about 40 years younger than me and she lives in my electorate, I am not too worried about that. It will be quite a long time before she is likely to be a serious threat to my personal circumstances.

This says some very good things not just about this young woman—about whom it says admirable things—but about our society: that from such a small but important discussion, positive action can flow, and that in our democracy the opportunity does exist for people, when they get an idea, to give it effective representation here in the highest forum of the country.

I am delighted to have the opportunity on behalf of everybody in the House—and I appreciate the positive responses of members opposite to this initiative—to say to Niamh Dobson, to the teachers who helped her and to everybody at Holy Trinity School in Curtin how impressed we are with the initiative and how pleased we are with the actions she has taken and that she has been able to see it through to its successful fulfilment today.

For the interest of the House, I would like to run through a bit more of the history of the villa Rhyndarra. It was constructed in 1889 by a Brisbane businessman, William Williams, and was designed by an architect called Andreo Stombuco. The building provided horse stables and so forth which were constructed in association with the house. When Rhyndarra was constructed, Williams owned some 140 acres of land at Yeronga—a tremendous part of Brisbane—which were surrounded on three sides by the Brisbane River. At this time the suburb of Yeronga was a mixture of large farming estates and smaller subdivisions for housing. Rhyndarra was typical of the large and pretentious houses constructed by many members of Brisbane's upper middle classes in the late 19th century.

The estate was divided into a number of sites, with Rhyndarra and an area of 12 acres later being bought by William Booth and the Salvation Army. The Salvation Army operated a home on the site for orphaned and other young girls from Rhyndarra. The stables were converted for use as a schoolroom.

Rhyndarra was later adapted to accommodate a large number of young women who were resident in the institution. In the early 1930s there were more than 60 girls in the home, ranging in age from babies to early teenagers. The Salvation Army ran the home until the 1940s, when the army took over the site as part of the wartime mobilisation. The Allied Works Council, responsible for the coordination of the building infrastructure associated with the war effort, converted the place into a women's hospital. In 1946 the Rhyndarra site was purchased by the Commonwealth and was used for the recuperation of servicewomen and for medical check‐ups before they were demobbed.

Initially after the war it was allocated to the Department of Social Services as a civilian rehabilitation centre, with Immigration and Health departments also interested in the site. In the 1950s, the facility had buildings which could be cheaply and easily adapted to accommodate national service recruits and trainees and in 1951 became known as the National Service Training Hospital. In the 1960s it was known as 1 Camp Hospital. More recently, as 1 Military Hospital it has provided a minor medical facility for soldiers who are injured or fall sick as a result of training.

Now the site is going to change hands yet again and the next stage of the disposal process, which is about to commence, will address the site's heritage value more closely, addressing such issues as the significance of the World War II elements, the social importance of the facility within the community, conservation and landscape matters, and recommendations on conservation and possible future uses for the site. I am delighted the minister has recognised that, like me, many locals are concerned about what does happen to this site. He has gladly agreed to community consultation.

BREAK.PARA: My only concern is that a lot of what will eventually happen there rests with the Brisbane City Council as the planning authority. I certainly hope the Brisbane City Council does not go down the ideological path of high density housing on the site, which is something the local residents do not want. The Brisbane City Council may be very tempted to go down this path, given their particular bent in other areas of my electorate. High density housing would be a disaster for the local residents, who have enjoyed the army as good neighbours for so many years. It would not be in keeping with the prestige and history of Rhyndarra as a heritage building; in fact, it would detract greatly from its value as a heritage site. I for one will be working very hard with the minister to make sure locals get their way on the future of the Rhyndarra property.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing I will say about this Howard government is that by coming up with a new, more objectionable policy with each passing day it makes it increasingly difficult to find enough rage now to cover all the offensive proposals it has made in previous weeks. The case in point is the 12 per cent cut that waits in the wings for the higher education sector. After the uproar following Senator Vanstone's slip—she thought a 12 per cent cut would do for starters—the issue seems to have gone off the boil. That is not to say that Australians have resigned themselves to the cuts; it is more that we have had our attention now grabbed by a number of the government's other almost equally reprehensible policies and proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to place the issue back on the boil and, in particular, to point out to the House what cuts of that magnitude would do to the university in my area, the University of Western Sydney. As a person who has served my area of western Sydney since 1971 at all levels of government, I have watched the University of Western Sydney grow from being merely a glint in the eye of the Hawke government to the internationally acclaimed institution that it has now become.

BREAK.PARA: Let me acquaint the House of the University of Western Sydney's importance for the rest of western Sydney, via a few facts and figures. The University of Western Sydney is the region's second biggest employer, and one of the main users of local businesses and industry. As such, it contributes greatly to local economic and social growth. In its first six years it produced 25,000 graduates—a trained work force for Sydney's west.

The University of Western Sydney serves 40 per cent of Sydney's population and nearly 10 per cent of Australia's population. Because of the size of the population it serves, the University of Western Sydney can only offer students in the west eight places per 1,000 inhabitants, whereas the rest of Sydney can offer 32 places per 1,000 people.

Some 58 per cent of University of Western Sydney students are the first in their family ever to attend university. At 7,393 students, it has the largest number of undergraduates new to higher education than any other university in Australia. More than 25 per cent of University of Western Sydney students come from non-English speaking backgrounds. More than 55 per cent of its students are women. Of the University of Western Sydney's 23,000 students, 65 per cent live in the Greater Western Sydney region and 50 per cent of all students find work in the area upon graduation.

Any cuts, whether they be five per cent, 10 per cent or 12 per cent, will cut deep into the heart of the educational services which the university now offers to the people of western Sydney. It will not only rob the rest of university places, which are already as scarce as hen's teeth compared to the rest of Sydney, but also impact disastrously on jobs and the economy which surrounds the university.

As the second largest employer, possibly now even the largest, in western Sydney, I think a 12 per cent cut in the University of Western Sydney's funding would be like stabbing the economic heart of the region itself. A 12 per cent cut in the University of Western Sydney's Commonwealth funding would translate to a loss of $24 million, or 2,000 students.

We will not accept such a vindictive attack on the families and children of ordinary working class Australians. If we are to maintain people's dignity, if we are to preserve the undeniable right of the people of western Sydney to obtain higher levels of education, we cannot and will not accept such an attack.

Greater Western Sydney traditionally has been a region underresourced in higher education—a situation which has not been completely corrected. Yet we have come so far. Why is the government intent on slapping down the achievements and the work of so many people from western Sydney? Why is it determined to frustrate the dreams of so many young people in my area who, after such cuts, will no longer be able to gain a university place and, as such, will have their career expectations thwarted?

In a perfect world, education would be completely free. We all know that, but we all know that that is not possible. Yet education need not be wrenched from the grasp of people who traditionally cannot afford university fees and charges. We need not return to the days when higher education was a privilege of the rich. Or is that the government's true desire? It seems as though it might be, because that is where its ideology of cuts to higher education is leading it.

Cuts of 12 per cent will severely retard the growth of the University of Western Sydney, and a similar flow‐on effect will be felt throughout the entire western Sydney region. I strongly advise the new member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly), the new member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron), who is in the House tonight, the new member for Macquarie (Mr Bartlett), and even the new member for Macarthur (Mr Fahey), the Minister for Finance, to think again. I advise them to think of the needs of the people they now serve and to go into bat for the University of Western Sydney. At the very least, they should think how, three years from now, they could live to regret their lack of action today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on the urgent need for a 40‐bed nursing home in the city of Armadale in my electorate of Canning. I raised this issue in my first speech when I came here. I stated then that appropriate facilities for the elderly in my electorate are acutely scarce and I identified the need for more nursing home beds as well as alternative accommodation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no secret that Australia has an ageing population. In fact, Western Australia's number of seniors as a proportion of the population is expected to grow to more than 22 per cent in the year 2021. This figure was only 14 per cent in 1991. This will see the number of persons aged 65 and over increasing from just under 160,000 to 460,000 persons. This is a major challenge for both the state and federal governments. We need to have plans in place to ensure that health and aged care provision are dealt with.

The Western Australian state government has estimated that the state may require an additional 39,400 nursing beds by the year 2026. With respect to my electorate of Canning, and in particular the city of Armadale, there has been a dire need for many years to build a nursing home in that area. Figures show that currently 25 per cent of persons residing in the south‐east corridor of the Perth metropolitan area—of which Armadale comprises a major area—are over the age of 60 years, and this figure is growing steadily. A projected figure indicates that a 31 per cent increase in the number of aged persons living within the Armadale area over the next 10 years can be expected.

Dale Cottages, a non-profit organisation dedicated to caring for the aged, have been pushing for a new nursing home since 1990. Dale Cottages management has predicted that 30 additional jobs will be created by building this new nursing home, with obvious ongoing economic and social spin-offs for local industry. Dale Cottages already have the land set aside with all the necessary infrastructure, such as sewerage and power, and preliminary plans for a possible new nursing home have also already been made by them.

A planning seminar examining future trends in relation to an ageing population in the city of Armadale found that, notwithstanding the trend for seniors to remain in their own homes for longer, Armadale was in urgent need of a nursing home. This planning seminar indicated that it would press for funds from the federal government and press government to change its policy on bed allocations per head of population.

Since becoming the member for Canning in March this year, I have been lobbied intensely by a wide variety of individuals and interested parties on the need for a nursing home in this area. I believe that this need is extreme and urgent, and I will do my utmost as the people's representative for Canning to ensure that this need is met.

When the Council of Australian Governments met in Canberra earlier this month, it agreed that there is an urgent need to shift the focus of health and community services from programs to people through a partnership between the Commonwealth and states. I hope that, as the responsibility for aged care services is devolved to the states, I will continue to play an active and constructive role regarding this matter.

I believe Dale Cottages to be uniquely placed. As I have already mentioned, they have the land and the infrastructure, and preliminary planning is already in place. They are also willing to help with funding, if possible. They have demonstrated that they are also willing to do something for the aged in the city of Armadale. I hope the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) and her department look favourably on the need for a nursing home in the city of Armadale during their budget deliberations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In this week of national action about skillshare, I wish to place on record my support for the program. There is no clearer evidence of the total policy disarray of this government than the savage treatment that has been handed out to skillshare projects.

SPEECH.PARA: We must remember that skillshare is acknowledged to be a cost effective program that gets results. In the past the effectiveness and success of this program has been acknowledged, almost on a bipartisan basis. One only has to look back to Fightback, the most pernicious manifesto ever put before an Australian electorate, for evidence of this. Fightback praised skillshare:
Skillshare type training programs, which encourage strong community based/non-government sector involvement will form a key part of the coalition's approach to training.
That is a quote from Fightback.

The National Skillshare Association has stated that it was assured by the coalition before the election that skillshare was not going to be cut. Following the election, the effectiveness of skillshare was acknowledged by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone.

Now skillshares are having to deal with a savage unilateral cut of one-third in their funding. Despite the most recent announcements on funding of last week that indicate it is only a 20 per cent cut, it must be remembered that the additional funds that were found last week are not for the skillshare program but for job clubs to be conducted by skillshares. This one-third funding cut is an appalling decision. It combines the worst elements of bad policy and bad process, and exposes the government's total lack of understanding of the community's needs.

Australians did not vote for this. There is no mandate for this. There is no need for it. The people this decision hurts the most are the unemployed—those least able to defend themselves. It is so easy to work out who the winners and losers are under a coalition government.

The authors of this decision have clearly never attended a skillshare graduation cere‐ mony. Three skillshares that operate in my electorate—Mature Action, Skillseekers and Employment 2000 Plenty Valley—have a longstanding record for providing effective and efficient services. Over the years they have helped many hundreds of people, some of them among the most disadvantaged job seekers in the labour market, back into the work force.
I have been provided with copies of letters that have been sent to the department by past participants of skillshare. Let me provide the following quotation. One person writes:

Having completed two courses made available through mature action skillshare, I have successfully gained full‐time employment. I know without this training I would have been at a loss as to know where to begin in seeking employment. I had, for 10 years prior to taking these courses, been a full‐time carer in the home.
There are many other examples, Mr Speaker, that I could read to you of testimonies of the help that has been given. As the slogan says: cutting skillshare doesn't make cents.
